Figure 5 is a graphical depiction of the IEEE 802.11 channel mappings.
Note: In the United States at the time of publication, the transmission channel is a value of 180, and a value of 183.

children.heading: Store a Message's Transmission Start Time

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the start date and time that a stored message is to begin transmission.

children.heading: Store a Message's Transmission Stop Time

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the stop date and time that a stored message is to end transmission.

children.heading: Store if a Message is to be Signed

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store if the payload of the stored message is to be signed prior to forwarding the message for transmission to the V2X wireless interface. A RSU has three options for signing the payload of a stored message: sign, which is to sign and wrap the message into an appropriate security header; do-not-sign, which still wraps the message into a security header but without signing the message; and bypass, which transmits the payload "as-is" without even wrapping the message into a security header. This last option assumes that the transmitter of the payload already put the appropriate security header into the payload.
Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store a message for future transmission.

Note: This previously available requirement to store a message has been deprecated in NTCIP 1218 v01A. This replacement was made because the payload size was increased to support LTE-V2X communications. The previously available requirement can be found in 3.5.1.2.2.1.2. See Annex D.1.1 for more information regarding this change from v01 to v01A of NTCIP 1218.
The requirements for the RSU to manage messages received by the RSU for immediate transmission over the V2X interface follow.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Immediate Forward Messages Supported

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of message types received for forwarding that can supported on the RSU.

children.heading: Forward Message to the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store a received message to be forwarded immediately to the V2X interface for transmission. The received message shall be authenticated and from a trusted source.

discussion.comment:
The title and traced user need suggests a need for a true forwarding service (i.e., an incoming packet is forwarded to a different network interface at the network layer based on a configuration), which is not fulfilled by this requirement. The requirement suggests that the message is stored (e.g., as a standard SNMP operation rather than coming into a separate port) and immediately forwarded (i.e., still a single operation). The purpose of the storage is unclear.

The design also fails to satisfy the requirement or the user need. The design stores the message (one operation) and then allows a second operation to enable the forwarding of the message. 

separate action to send the message (i.e., by the ITS application entity; a higher-layer function). Either the need or the design need to be revised.

history.addedComment: The title suggests that this is message forwarding (i.e., a network layer issue), while the text states that the message will also be stored (i.e., potentially implying a higher-layer issue). What is the intent of storing the message? Is this true network layer forwarding (where storing the message is strictly for auditing purposes) or is there additional functionality being implied (e.g., "store and repeatedly broadcast" so that it is "forwarded" to all vehicles for some duration). If the latter, then where is the meta-data describing how often it is transmitted and duration?

history.editLastComment: The title suggests that this is message forwarding (i.e., a network layer issue), while the text states that the message will also be stored (i.e., potentially implying a higher-layer issue). What is the intent of storing the message? Is this true network layer forwarding (where storing the message is strictly for auditing purposes) or is there additional functionality being implied (e.g., "store and repeatedly broadcast" so that it is "forwarded" to all vehicles for some duration). If the latter, then where is the meta-data describing how often it is transmitted and duration?

history.updatedComment: The title suggests that this is message forwarding (i.e., a network layer issue), while the text states that the message will also be stored (i.e., potentially implying a higher-layer issue). What is the intent of storing the message? Is this true network layer forwarding (i.e., the entire APDU is forwarded and the storage is strictly for auditing purposes) or is there additional functionality being implied (e.g., "store and repeatedly broadcast" so that it is "forwarded" to all vehicles for some duration). If the latter, then where is the meta-data describing how often it is transmitted and duration (i.e., the APDU potentially contains other data)?

The title suggests that this is message forwarding (i.e., a network layer issue), while the text states that the message will also be stored (i.e., potentially implying a higher-layer issue). What is the intent of storing the message? Is this true network layer forwarding (i.e., the entire APDU is forwarded and the storage is strictly for auditing purposes) or is there additional functionality being implied (e.g., "store and repeatedly broadcast" so that it is "forwarded" to all vehicles for some duration). If the latter, then where is the meta-data describing how often it is transmitted and duration (i.e., the APDU potentially contains other data)?

The title and traced user need suggests a need for a true forwarding service (i.e., an incoming packet is forwarded to a different network interface at the network layer), which is not fulfilled by this design. This design stores the message and then performs a separate action to send the message (i.e., by the ITS application entity; a higher-layer function). Either the need or the design need to be revised.

children.heading: Store the Message Type for a Message for Forwarding to the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the message type of a message received for forwarding to the V2X interface for transmission. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735.

children.heading: Store the PSID for an Application Data Exchange for Forwarding to the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the PSID for an application data exchange received for forwarding to the V2X interface for transmission.

children.heading: Store the Priority for a Message for Forwarding to the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the user priority assigned for a message received for forwarding to the V2X interface for transmission. For a V2X radio, the user priority is an integer value and is defined in IEEE 1609.3.

children.heading: Store the Transmission Channel for a Message for Forwarding to the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the transmission channel, as defined by the appropriate regulatory domain, that a received message for forwarding to the V2X interface is to be transmitted on. The valid values for the transmission channel are 0 to 255.

Note: For radios using IEEE 802.11, the transmission channel number is defined by IEEE 802.11. For PC5 radios, the equivalent transmission channel number is defined in Table 7, where EARFCN is the E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number.
Note: In the United States at the time of publication, the transmission channel is a value of 180 and a value of 183.

children.heading: Store if a Received Message for Forwarding to the V2X Interface is Signed

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store if the payload of a received message is to be signed prior to forwarding the message for transmission to the V2X interface. A RSU has three options for signing the payload of a received message for forwarding: sign, which is to sign and wrap the message into an appropriate security header; do-not-sign, which still wraps the message into a security header but without signing the message; and pass-through, which transmits the payload "as-is" without even wrapping the message into a security header. This last option assumes that the transmitter of the payload already put the appropriate security header into the payload.

children.heading: Manage Messages Received from the V2X Interface Requirements

children.text: The requirements for the RSU to manage messages received by the RSU over the V2X interface follow.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Message Received Types Supported

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of message types and message destinations for forwarding that can supported on the RSU.

children.heading: Store Network Destination to Forward Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the network address and port number that all messages received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID are to be forwarded to. A message with a specified PSID may be forwarded to more than one network address and port number.

children.heading: Store Transport Protocol to Forward Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the transport protocol to use to forward all messages received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID to a specified network address and port number.

children.heading: Store Minimum Signal Strength to Forward Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the minimum received signal strength indication (RSSI) level of the message received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID, before forwarding the message to a specified network address and port number. Valid RSSI levels are from -100 to -60 dbm in units of 1 dbm.

children.heading: Store Message Interval to Forward Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the message interval for forwarding messages received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID to a specified network address and port number. This requirement forwards every Nth message received by the V2X interface meeting all the specified criteria (PSID, RSSI) to the specified network address and port number. Valid values for n are from 1 to 9, with 1 indicating that all messages are to be forwarded.

children.heading: Store Start Time to Forward Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the start date and time that messages received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID are to be forwarded to a specified network address and port number.

children.heading: Store Stop Time to Forward Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the stop date and time that messages received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID are to stop being forwarded to a specified network address and port number.

children.heading: Enable/Disable Forwarding Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store if messages received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID are to be forwarded to a specified network address and port number.

children.heading: Store Secure Options to Forward Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store if only the payload content of the messages received from the V2X interface are forwarded to a specified network address and port number. This requirement allows the RSU is to strip any certificates and signatures from the message before forwarding the payload content.

children.heading: Store Interval to Authenticate Messages Received from the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the interval for authenticating messages received from the V2X interface with a specified PSID to a specified network address and port number and marked for forwarding. This requirement instructs the RSU to check the certificate and signature of every Nth message received by the V2X interface meeting all the specified criteria (PSID, RSSI) to the specified network address and port number and marked for forwarding (See 3.5.1.2.2.3.5). Valid values for n are from 1 to 9, with 1 indicating that all messages are to be forwarded. A value of 0 indicates that authentication is disabled.

children.heading: Forward Messages Transmitted Over the V2X Interface Requirements

children.text: The requirements for the RSU to forward to a specified network destination messages transmitted over the V2X interface follow.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Message Entries Transmitted Over the V2X Interface For Forwarding Supported

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of message types transmitted over the V2X interface and message destinations for forwarding that can supported on the RSU.

children.heading: Store Network Destination to Forward Messages Transmitted Over the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the network destination that the RSU forwards the messages that have been transmitted over the V2X interface with a specified PSID. The network destination consists of the IP address, the port number and a text description of the interface.

children.heading: Store Transport Protocol to Forward Messages Transmitted Over the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the transport protocol to use to forward the messages that have been transmitted over the V2X interface with a specified PSID.

children.heading: Store Start Time to Forward Messages Transmitted Over the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the start date and time that messages transmitted over the V2X interface with a specified PSID are to be forwarded to a specified network address and port number.

children.heading: Store Stop Time to Forward Messages Transmitted Over the V2X Interface

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the stop date and time that messages transmitted over the V2X interface with a specified PSID are to stop being forwarded to a specified network address and port number.
The requirements to manage the interface data logs for the RSU follow.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Interface Logs Supported

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of active interface logs that can be supported on the RSU.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store a list of interfaces for which the RSU shall log all transmitted and received packets.
Upon request from a management station and if the RSU is logging packets, the RSU shall generate separate log files for transmitted and received packets across a specified interface.

children.heading: Store Interface Data Log - File Directory

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the interface data logs in a specified directory on the RSU.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall return the logged data in the interface data log.

children.heading: Store an Interface Data Log Start Time

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the start date and time to begin logging data packets across a specified interface.

children.heading: Store an Interface Data Log Stop Time

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall store the stop date and time to stop logging data packets across a specified interface.

children.heading: Store Maximum Interface Data Log File Size

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the maximum file size supported by the RSU for an interface data log, in megabytes, from 1 to 40 megabytes. The RSU is to open a new interface data log file when an active interface data log reaches this maximum interface data log file size. This requirement allows the transportation manager to determine if there is sufficient space to continue storing interface data logs without crashing the RSU.

children.heading: Store Maximum Interface Data Log File Collection Time

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the minimum collection time supported by the RSU for an interface data log, in hours, from 1 to 48 hours. The RSU is to open a new interface data log file when an active interface data log reaches this maximum interface data log time.

children.heading: Store Interface Data Log Option - Disk Full

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store if the RSU is to stop interface data logging or delete the oldest interface data log file is the disk space available for interface data logs is full.

children.heading: Store Interface Data Log Option - Entry Deletion

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store if the RSU is to delete the interface data log file when its interface data log entry is deleted. It is assumed that a transportation manager retrieves the interface data log file from the RSU before deleting the interface data log entry from the RSU.
The requirements to configure the V2X interface for the RSU follow.
The requirements to configure the radios associated with the V2X interface for an RSU follow.

children.heading: Report Maximum Number of V2X Radios Supported

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of V2X radios supported by the RSU.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the type of V2X radios managed by the RSU. Valid values are dsrc and PC5.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall enable or disable a V2X radio managed by the RSU. This requirement allows a transportation manager to stop the radio from broadcasting and receiving messages.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the IEEE 802.11 MAC address of each V2X radio managed by the RSU. If the V2X interface is DSRC, it reports the MAC address; if the V2X radio is PC5, it reports the radio index (i.e. radio 1, radio 2, etc.).
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report if its V2X radios are operating in continuous or alternating modes.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the status of the communications for a V2X PC5 (LTE-V2X) radio.
The requirements to report the lower layer parameters associated with the V2X interface for an RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, if the V2X radio is a DSRC interface, the RSU shall report an enhanced distributed channel access (EDCA) parameter set for a V2X radio. The EDCA parameter set consists of, as defined in IEEE 802.11, the Arbitration Interframe Spacing (AIFSN), Contention Window Minimum Value (CWmin), Contention Window Maximum Value (CWmax), and the Transmission Opportunity (TXOP) limit.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the operating class, as defined in IEEE 802.11 or media used, that a V2X radio is configured for. Valid values for the operating class are from 0 to 255.
The requirements to configure the IEEE 1609 parameters for the RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall obtain and manage IEEE 1609.2 certificates to sign and encrypt messages for transmission via the radio. An RSU is expected to have two types of certificates, enrollment certificates and application certificates. Enrollment certificates are handled by the RSU manufacturer and contains the domain name URL where the application certificates would come from. The requirements to configure IEEE 1609.2 certificates for the RSU follow.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the status of the enrollment certificates. The valid values are notEnrolled, enrolled, unknown, and other.

children.heading: Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificate - Expiration Date

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the expiration date of the enrollment certificates.

children.heading: Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificate - Source Domain

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the domain uniform resource locator (URL) of the Certificate Authority that is the source of the enrollment certificate.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the certificate identifier associated with the Enrollment certificate. The identifier is the hexadecimal string representation of the IEEE 1609.2 HashedId8 of the Enrollment Certificate. The identifier, which should be human readable, is used to track the device's enrollment status via the SCMS.

children.heading: Report IEEE 1609.2 Enrollment Certificate - Valid Region

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report a region identifier, such as a country code, that the enrollment certificate is valid for. For the United States, the valid region identifier is the country code, 840.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report if the source of the enrollment certificates is the Security Credential Management System (SCMS) or the certificates were manually loaded (obtained).
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the status of the application certificates. The valid values are valid, notValid, future, expirationPending, other, and unknown.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the domain uniform resource locator (URL) from which to request new application certificates.

children.heading: Store IEEE 1609.2 Application Certificates - Default Request Interval

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the default interval, in hours, between new requests for application certificates.

children.heading: Store IEEE 1609.2 Application Certificates - Request Interval

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the interval, in hours, between new requests for application certificates for a specified PSID.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) URL, in the format defined by RFC 4701, from which to request updated certificate revocation lists.

attributesChanged.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) URL from which to request updated certificate revocation lists. See RFC 4701 for the definition of a FQDN.

children.heading: Report Certificate Revocation List - Update Time

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the date and time the certificate revocation list was last updated.

children.heading: Store Certificate Revocation List Update Interval

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the interval, in hours, between requests for an updated certificate revocation list.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall make a request to update its certificate revocation list from the certificate authority.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the name and description of the IEEE 1609.2 security profile for a PSID stored on the RSU. A security profile proforma is defined in IEEE 1609.2.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the number of days before the application certificate expires. Within this number of days, the application certificate status is changed to expirationPending. This requirement sets a flag to indicate that application certificates are close to expiring.

The requirements to configure the WAVE Service Advertisement (WSA) for the RSU follow. Broadcast messages from a V2X radio are not required to be preceded by or associated with a WSA. Note that the WSA is identified as an application that has a unique PSID and potentially a unique certificate. Refer to 3.5.1.3.3.1 for application certificate requirements.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Services Advertised

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of PSIDs that can be advertised by the RSU.

children.heading: Store WSA Configuration - Service Info Segment

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store a service info segment for a WSA. A service info segment for a WSA is defined in IEEE 1609.3 and provides information about a service, which is usually an application that is advertised by and accessible from or through the RSU. A service info segment consists of the PSID; the Provider Service Context (PSC) information; the IPv6 address, port number and provider MAC address used to access the application service; the RCPI threshold; the WSA count threshold, WSA count threshold interval, and if the service is a routed service. All elements in the service info segment are optional except the PSID. Note that a WSA is not required to support broadcast messages.

attributesChanged.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store a service info segment for a WSA. A service info segment for a WSA is defined in IEEE 1609.3 and provides information about a service, which is usually an application that is advertised by and accessible from or through the RSU. A service info segment consists of the PSID; the Provider Service Context (PSC) information; the IPv6 address, port number and provider MAC address used to access the application service; the RCPI threshold; the WSA count threshold, WSA count threshold interval, and if the service is a routed service. All elements in the service info segment are optional except the PSID. Note that a WSA is not required to support broadcast messages.

children.heading: Store WSA Configuration - Channel Info Segment

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the desired transmission information for a service provided by the RSU. The transmission information consists of the operating class, the transmission channel (number) to advertise the service, the transmit power level to be used, and the transmission interval for the advertisement. The RSU uses this information to advertise services on the appropriate transmission channels, power levels, and intervals.

children.heading: Configure WSA Configuration - WAVE Router Advertisement

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall configure a WAVE router advertisement (WRA) segment for a WSA. A WRA segment for a WSA is defined in IEEE 1609.3 and provides information to configure an IPv6 interface so messages received from a connected device via the V2X can be immediately exchanged with a remote host. A WRA contains the network address of the remote host, the network gateway, the primary Domain Name System (DNS), and optionally the network address of the secondary DNS and gateway MAC address.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface are to be secure (signed) or unsecure.

Note: This requirement has been replaced in NTCIP 1218 v01A because NTCIP 1218 v01 incorrectly allows a management station to configure whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface is secure or unsecure based on the PSID. The replacement can be found in 3.5.1.3.3.2.7. See Annex D.1.2 for more information regarding this change from v01 to v01A of NTCIP 1218.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the WSA Version Number, as defined in IEEE 1609.3, used by the RSU.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface is to be secure (signed) or unsecure. In practice, the WSA should always be secure.

Note: This previously available requirement to store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface is to be secure (signed) or unsecure has been deprecated in NTCIP 1218 v01A. This replacement was made because the configuration is not based on the PSID but applies to the entire WSA. The previously available requirement can be found in 3.5.1.3.3.2.5. See Annex D.1.2 for more information regarding this change from v01 to v01A of NTCIP 1218.

children.heading: Store WSA Configuration – WAVE Routing Advertisement

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface includes WAVE Routing Advertisement information.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface includes the Repeat Rate. The Repeat Rate indicates the number of times the WSA is transmitted per 5 seconds.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface includes the latitude-longitude location of the WSA transmit antenna.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface includes the three-dimensional location of the WSA transmit antenna. See IEEE 1609.3 for how elevation is represented.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the WSA transmitted over the V2X interface includes the Received Channel Power Indicator (RCPI) threshold. The RCPI threshold indicates the recommended minimum received WSA signal value, in dBm, below which the application service should be ignored by a recipient.

children.heading: Report WSA Configuration – Extended Channel Information

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the WSA extended channel information segment field for LTE-V2X, as defined in IEEE 1609.3 Section M.6.2.
The requirements to configure the RSU for multi-channel operations follow. These requirements apply only to DSRC radios.

children.heading: Store the IEEE 1609.4 Configuration for a Radio

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the parameters for a radio. The parameters consist of a textual description of the radio, the service channel and the transmission channels the radio operates on as defined by the appropriate regulatory domain. The valid values for the transmission channels are 0 to 255.
Note: For radios using IEEE 802.11, the transmission channel number is defined by IEEE 802.11.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the channel access options (continuous, alternating, immediate) of the radio, and if the immediate or extended option for channel switching is used (if applicable). The valid values for channel access options are continuous, alternating, immediate, other and unknown. The channel access mode for an LTE-V2X radio is continuous access.
The requirements to configure the radio transmitter properties associated with the V2X interface for an RSU follow.

For a message with a specified PSID forwarded to a radio for transmission, upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the default transmit power level, in dBm, at the antenna port to be used for transmission for a channel. The valid range for the default power is from -128 to 127 dBm, in units of 1 dBm.
Note: The default transmit power could be dynamic and changed by channel or an application.

children.heading: Report Maximum Number of V2X Antennas Supported

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of V2X antennas supported by the RSU.

children.heading: Store Antenna Gain and Cable Losses

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the antenna gain for a radio antenna, in units of 0.01 dB. This requirement is applicable if the antenna is not direct connect.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the direction that the antenna is pointing at along the horizontal plane. A value of 360 indicates uniform gain in all directions in the horizontal plane.
The requirements for managing the applications on the RSU follow.
The requirements for managing an application on the RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, an RSU shall support the installation of new or updated software from an authorized source. The installation process allows the transmission of the secure installation files, executable application code and associated support files to support the installation files, and confirmation of a successful update of the software.
Note: The expectation is that the management station loads the installation files to the RSU.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the status of the process to install software, and the date and time the status was last updated. The valid values for status are the following: rejected, roll-backed, processing, successful, and unknown. An attempt to update the software may be rejected for a security reason, such as it has not been authenticated. If applicable, if an attempt to update the software fails, the software should be roll-backed to the pre-update version.
The requirements for managing the configuration of an application on the RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, an RSU shall begin the installation of a configuration file from an authorized source. The installation allows the transmission of the secure installation files and associated support files to support the installation files, and confirmation of a successful update of the application or process.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the status of the process to install an updated configuration file, and the date and time the status was last updated. The valid values for status are the following: rejected, roll-backed, processing, successful, and unknown. An attempt to update the configuration file may be rejected for a security reason, such as it has not been authenticated. If an attempt to update the configuration file fails, the configuration file should be rolled-back to the pre-update version.
The requirements to support an RLVW application on the RSU follow.

children.heading: Receive Movement Maneuver Assist – NTCIP 1202 v03B

children.text: Upon request from a traffic signal controller, the RSU shall store movement maneuver assist information for a signalized intersection. The movement maneuver assist information from the traffic signal controller consists of the signal group identifier the assist information is for, the vehicle queue length for that movement maneuver, and if any conflicting pedestrians or bicyclists are detected for that movement maneuver through the intersection. The movement maneuver assist information shall be provided in a format defined by NTCIP 1202 v03B.

attributesChanged.text: Upon request from a traffic signal controller, the RSU shall store movement maneuver assist information for a signalized intersection. The movement maneuver assist information from the traffic signal controller consists of the signal group identifier the assist information is for, the vehicle queue length for that movement maneuver, and if any conflicting pedestrians or bicyclists are detected for that movement maneuver through the intersection. The movement maneuver assist information is provided in a format defined by NTCIP 1202 v03B.

children.text: Upon request from a traffic signal controller, the RSU shall store speed advisories for a signalized intersection. The speed advisory information from the traffic signal controller consists of the signal group identifier the advisory is for, the advisory speed, the advisory speed type, the distance from the stop bar the advisory speed is effective for, and the vehicle types the speed advisory is intended for. The speed advisory information shall be provided in a format defined by NTCIP 1202 v03B.

attributesChanged.text: Upon request from a traffic signal controller, the RSU shall store speed advisories for a signalized intersection. The speed advisory information from the traffic signal controller consists of the signal group identifier the advisory is for, the advisory speed, the advisory speed type, the distance from the stop bar the advisory speed is effective for, and the vehicle types the speed advisory is intended for. The speed advisory information is provided in a format defined by NTCIP 1202 v03B.

children.heading: Receive SPaT Movement Status – NTCIP 1202 v03B

children.text: Upon request from a traffic signal controller, the RSU shall store SPaT information for a signalized intersection. The SPaT information from the traffic signal controllers consists of the intersection status, the enabled lanes in effect, and movement data for the intersection containing what vehicle (or pedestrian) movements are permitted and when. The SPaT information shall be provided in a format defined by NTCIP 1202 v03B.

attributesChanged.text: Upon request from a traffic signal controller, the RSU shall store SPaT information for a signalized intersection. The SPaT information from the traffic signal controllers consists of the intersection status, the enabled lanes in effect, and movement data for the intersection containing what vehicle (or pedestrian) movements are permitted and when. The SPaT information is provided in a format defined by NTCIP 1202 v03B.

children.text: The requirements for managing location corrections data provided by the RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall forward location corrections data received from an external source for transmission via the V2X interface. Examples of location corrections data are RTCM Corrections messages as recommended in SAE J2735.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall receive and transmit the RTCM SC-104 Corrections messages received from a validated external source.
The requirements for monitoring the operation of the RSU device follow.

children.heading: Determine RSU Operational Performance Status Requirements

children.text: The requirements for monitoring the operational performance for the RSU follow.

children.heading: Report Time Elapsed Since RSU Power On

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the amount of time that has elapsed since it has been powered on, in seconds.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the amount of free volatile memory, in megabytes, available on the RSU.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the CPU load of the RSU at the time of the request, in percentage, from 0 to 100 percent.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the average CPU load of the RSU for the previous 15 minutes, in percentage, from 0 to 100 percent.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the average CPU load of the RSU for the previous 5 minutes, in percentage, from 0 to 100 percent.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the average CPU load of the RSU for the previous minute, in percentage, from 0 to 100 percent.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the amount of non-volatile available storage space, in megabytes. The storage space in the RSU may be used to store interface data logs, applications, etc.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the number of messages transmitted and received over the V2X interface, sorted by channel and direction (transmitted or received), since the RSU was last rebooted or since the time the RSU was commanded to begin tracking the number of messages exchanged.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Monitored PSID Messages

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the number of PSIDs that can be monitored for the number of messages exchanged over the V2X interface, by channel and direction (transmitted or received).
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current mode of operation of the RSU. Valid values are standby, operate, and fault.
In 'standby' mode, the RSU's V2X radio is not enabled and interface logging is disabled.

The RSU is in 'operate' mode when V2X radio is enabled (transmitting and receiving), system logging is enabled, and periodic communications with a management station (e.g., an operations center) is enabled.

In 'fault' mode, the RSU is not fully functional, only minimally responsive and is not transmitting messages over the V2X interface. For example, the RSU may enter fault mode if the RSU fails to properly reboot (e.g., all system drivers or firmware do not properly start) after a configurable number of attempts.
The requirements for managing the clock of an RSU follow.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the primary clock source for the RSU. The valid values are crystal, GNSS, NTP, and other.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the status of the system clock in the RSU. The valid values are active and pending update.

children.heading: Store Allowable RSU Clock Source Timeout

history.addedComment: Does this address the "timeout performance requirement" mentioned in NTCIP-8?

history.updatedComment: Does this address the "timeout performance requirement" mentioned in NTCIP-8?

history.removedComment: Does this address the "timeout performance requirement" mentioned in NTCIP_1218-8?

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store a timeout value, from 1 to 3,600 seconds, representing the allowable amount of time that communications from the primary time source may be lost.

children.heading: Store Allowable RSU Clock Source Queries

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the number of allowable consecutive failed query attempts, from 1 to 15, for time information from the primary time source.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the allowable deviation, in milliseconds, between two or more time sources.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store whether the NTP server is enabled or disabled. This requirement allows the RSU to be an NTP server if the RSU is connected to a precise time source, such as GNSS.
The requirements for the RSU to determine its location information follow.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall return its current location as reported by a GNSS or similar geopositioning device. The RSU location consists of the latitude, longitude, and elevation. The latitude and longitude are measured in tenths of a microdegrees (10^-7 degrees) based on the WGS-84 (World Geodetic System 1984). The elevation of the RSU is in centimeters above the reference ellipsoid as defined by WGS-84 and is measured to the base of the GNSS antenna.

Note: For locations where GNSS signals are not sufficient to report its current location (e.g., in a long tunnel), the forthcoming Side Link Syncronization Service (SLSS) specified in J3161 and J3161/1 is supposed to solve this issue.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall return the number of satellites, from 0 to 15, the GNSS or similar geopositioning device is tracking.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the maximum allowable tolerance, in centimeters, between the last location reported by a GNSS or similar geopositioning device and the RSU's reference location. The tolerance is reported as the distance between the two coordinates (longitude and latitude), from 1 to 20,000 meters. This requirement is used by the RSU to determine if a notification should be transmitted to a management station.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the deviation, in centimeters, between the location reported by a GNSS or similar geopositioning device and the RSU's reference location.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the estimated location error the GNSS or similar geopositioning device is experiencing. The estimated location error is defined along the semi-major axis, semi-minor axis, and orientation, as defined by DF_PositionalAccuracy in SAE J2735.
The requirements for the RSU to monitor its network interfaces follow.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall return the number of communications errors that have occurred on an Ethernet port. Communications errors include a bad CRC and framing errors resulting in a corrupted message.

children.heading: Report Number of Messages Exchanged by V2X Radio and PSID

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the number of messages transmitted and received by the RSU, sorted by PSID and V2X radio, over the radio since the RSU was last powered on or the RSU was rebooted. If the application is IP-based, the RSU stores the number of messages comprising the entire corresponding data exchange.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report which V2X radios are active.
Requirements to determine the effective RF communications range for V2X communications around the RSU follow.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Communications Range Entries

children.text: Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of communications range entries that can be supported on the RSU. Each entry represents the communications range statistics based on a message type, a vehicle type or vehicle class, and one or more of 16 22.5 degree sectors.

children.heading: Report the RF Communications Distance - 1 Minute

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the farthest distance, in meters, from the location of the RSU by sector that a message was received via the V2X interface over the previous 1 minute by message type and vehicle type. This requirement allows an RSU to determine the radio coverage in each of 16 22.5 degree sectors around the RSU. The first sector starts from North and ends at 22.5 degrees from North in an eastward direction and the distance is measured in tenths of a meter. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735. The vehicle type is defined by DE_VehicleType, as defined in SAE J2735, which represents the FHWA 13-Vehicle Category Classification. A distance of 0 meters indicates no messages are received.

children.heading: Report the RF Communications Distance - 5 Minutes

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the farthest distance, in meters, from the location of the RSU by sector that a message was received via the V2X interface over the previous 5 minutes by message type and vehicle type. This requirement allows an RSU to determine the radio coverage in each of sixteen 22.5 degree sectors around the RSU. The first sector starts from North and ends at 22.5 degrees from North in an eastward direction and the distance is measured in tenths of a meter. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735. The vehicle type is defined by DE_VehicleType, as defined in SAE J2735, which represents the FHWA 13-Vehicle Category Classification. A distance of 0 meters indicates no messages are received.

children.heading: Report the RF Communications Distance - 15 Minutes

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the farthest distance, in meters, from the location of the RSU by sector that a message was received via the V2X interface over the previous 15 minutes by message type and vehicle type. This requirement allows an RSU to determine the radio coverage in each of 16 22.5 degree sectors around the RSU. The first sector starts from North and ends at 22.5 degrees from North in an eastward direction and the distance is measured in tenths of a meter. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735. The vehicle type is defined by DE_VehicleType, as defined in SAE J2735, which represents the FHWA 13-Vehicle Category Classification. A distance of 0 meters indicates no messages are received.

children.heading: Report the Average RF Communications Distance - 1 Minute

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the average farthest distance from the location of the RSU by sector from which a message was received via the V2X interface over the previous 1 minute by message type and vehicle type. This requirement assumes that the RSU has the ability to determine when a mobile device is first or last detected by the RSU within a sector. This calculation is a simple average of the location of each mobile device detected by the RSU in the previous 1 minute. This requirement allows an RSU to determine the radio coverage in each of 16 22.5 degree sectors around the RSU. The first sector starts from North and ends at 22.5 degrees from North in an eastward direction and the distance is measured in tenths of a meter. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735. The vehicle type is defined by DE_VehicleType, as defined in SAE J2735, which represents the FHWA 13-Vehicle Category Classification. A distance of 0 meters indicates no messages are received.

children.heading: Report the Average RF Communications Distance - 5 Minutes

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the average farthest distance from the location of the RSU by sector from which a message was received via the V2X interface over the previous 5 minutes by message type and vehicle type. This requirement assumes that the RSU has the ability to determine when a mobile device is first or last detected by the RSU within a sector. This calculation is a simple average of the location of each mobile device detected by the RSU in the previous 5 minutes. This requirement allows an RSU to determine the radio coverage in each of 16 22.5 degree sectors around the RSU. The first sector starts from North and ends at 22.5 degrees from North in an eastward direction and the distance is measured in tenths of a meter. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735. The vehicle type is defined by DE_VehicleType, as defined in SAE J2735, which represents the FHWA 13-Vehicle Category Classification. A distance of 0 meters indicates no messages are received.

children.heading: Report the Average RF Communications Distance - 15 Minutes

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the average farthest distance from the location of the RSU by sector from which a message was received via the V2X interface over the previous 15 minutes by message type and vehicle type. This requirement assumes that the RSU has the ability to determine when a mobile device is first or last detected by the RSU within a sector. This calculation is a simple average of the location of each mobile device detected by the RSU in the previous 15 minutes. This requirement allows an RSU to determine the radio coverage in each of 16 22.5 degree sectors around the RSU. The first sector starts from North and ends at 22.5 degrees from North in an eastward direction and the distance is measured in tenths of a meter. The message type is identified by the DE_DSRC_MessageID data element, as defined in SAE J2735. The vehicle type is defined by DE_VehicleType, as defined in SAE J2735, which represents the FHWA 13-Vehicle Category Classification. A distance of 0 meters indicates no messages are received.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the parameters for measuring the farthest and average farthest distance a message was received via the V2X interface over a predefined period (1-, 5-, and 15- minutes). Each set of parameters consists of a message type, a vehicle type or vehicle class, and one or more of 16 22.5 degree sectors.
Upon request by a management station, the RSU shall report the status of an application on the RSU. The status of the application is defined by if the application is active or not.
Requirements for retrieving the configuration parameters for the RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the internal temperature of the RSU enclosure in degrees Celsius. The valid values are from -100 to 100 degrees Celsius, and an additional value indicating unknown temperature.

children.heading: Determine the Internal Operating Temperature Thresholds

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the internal temperature thresholds for the RSU enclosure in degrees Celsius. The valid values are from -100 to 100 degrees Celsius, and an additional value indicating unknown temperature. The RSU is to transmit a notification if the internal temperature exceeds the temperature thresholds.
The requirements to report the current status of the RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the overall summary current state of the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the RSU fully operational with no errors detected that impacts its operation, i.e., all services provided by the RSU are okay. Warning indicates the RSU is operating, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation, e.g., wrong configuration, firewall not active. Critical indicates an error that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., time source lost or a service crashed.
The requirements to retrieve the status of services provided by the RSU follow.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the system services on the RSU. System services include CPU usage and memory usage. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the system services is fully operational with no errors detected that impacts its operation. Warning indicates the system services is operational, but an error is detected which may affect its operation, e.g., low system memory available. Critical indicates an error is detected that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., no system memory available.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the GNSS service on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the GNSS service is fully functional with no errors detected. Warning indicates the GNSS service is operational, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation, e.g., poor signal strength, signal from less than five satellites available. Critical indicates an error is detected that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., no GNSS signal detected.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the time source on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the RSU's primary time source is fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates that an issue with the time source is detected, which may affect RSU operations, e.g., non-primary time source not detected, no valid time data from the primary time source but secondary time source is available, or tolerable deviation between two or more different time sources detected. Critical indicates an error is detected that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., primary clock source timeout and no other time source available.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the storage available for storing logs on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates that sufficient storage is available for storing new log data, including removable storage (e.g., SD card). Warning indicates the available storage may be insufficient based on the current calculated storage needs. The Warning threshold may be vendor-defined or agency-defined but should be based on what the expected storage needs when considering what logging is currently enabled or scheduled. Critical indicates that no storage is available for saving logged data on the RSU (even if the RSU is writing over older log files).

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the access control (e.g., firewall) service on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the access control service is fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates the access control service is operating, but an issue is detected which may compromise security, e.g., a potentially unauthorized request is detected. Critical indicates an error is detected that may comprise RSU security, e.g., the access control service has timed out.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the network services on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, citical, and unknown. Okay indicates the network services are fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates that an issue is detected with the network which may affect RSU operations, e.g., communications timeout. Critical indicates an error is detected that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., communications timeout with a management station.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the radio access services, such as layers 1 and 2 of the radio access technology, on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the radio services are fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates the radio access services are operating, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation. Critical indicates an error that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., the RSU has insufficient precision timing to perform alternating radio mode or no response from the V2X radio.

children.heading: Report V2X Radio Networking Services Status

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the V2X radio networking services, such as layers 3 and 4 of the radio access technology on the RSU. For DSRC radios, this represents IEEE 1609.3. Valid values are okay, warning, critical and unknown. Okay indicates the radio networking services are fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates the radio networking services are operating, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation, e.g., wrong configuration. Critical indicates an error that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., the Ethernet interface is down or the DNS is unavailable.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of IEEE 1609.2 certificates on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the status of the IEEE 1609.2 certificates is fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates the services that use IEEE 1609.2 certificates are operational, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation, e.g., the number of valid IEEE 1609.2 certificates are low, or there is an IEEE 1609.2 application certificate expiring within 7 days. Critical indicates an error that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., no more valid IEEE 1609.2 certificates are available.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the SCMS service on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the SCMS service is fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates the SCMS service is operating, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation, e.g., the enrollment certificates are expiring within 7 days. Critical indicates an error is detected that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., the enrollment certificates are invalid.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of vendor specific services on the RSU. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the vendor specific service is operating properly with no errors detected and that impacts its operation. Warning indicates the vendor specific service is operating, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation. Critical indicates the vendor specific service may not be operating or an error is detected that has a significant impact on the RSU operation.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report a detailed description of the cause of the current status of an RSU service. For example, the description may describe what event caused an RSU service to have a current state of Critical.

children.heading: Report RSU Services Status Update Time

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the date and time the current state of a RSU was last updated. This requirement allows a transportation operator to determine when an event that caused the service to enter a Warning or Critical state occurred.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current state of the NTP Server service on the RSU. The NTP service allows the RSU to be a NTPv4 compliant server, as defined in RFC 5905. Valid values are okay, warning, critical, and unknown. Okay indicates the NTP service is fully operational with no errors detected. Warning indicates the NTP service is operating, but an issue is detected which may affect its operation, e.g., the RSU has not received a valid time update from the primary time source in 1 second. Critical indicates an error is detected that has a significant impact on the RSU operation, e.g., the RSU has not received a valid time update from the primary time source that exceeds the timeout period (See 3.5.2.3.3).
Note: This requirement is mandatory if the RSU is to be a NTPv4 compliant server.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the current mode of the NTP, as defined in RFC 5907.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Services Supported

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the maximum number of services supported by the RSU.
The requirements for controlling the RSU device follow.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall change its mode of operation as requested. Valid modes of operation are fully operational, and standby mode.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall set the transmit power of a RF channel as effective isotropic radiated power (EIRP), in dBm. The transmit power is required to comply with the appropriate regulatory domain.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall (warm) reboot the RSU.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall enable or disable an application (process) on the RSU.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store if the RSU uses the last saved value, or the user-configured default settings upon (warm) rebooting the RSU. See CTI 4001, Section 3.3.2.2.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall enable or disable signing messages, which would otherwise be signed by the RSU based on other settings. When disabled, the RSU transmits all WAVE messages with the IEEE Std 1609.2™ header Ieee1609Dot2Data.unsecuredData.
To prevent potential abuse, the RSU will always restart in a state so the RSU is signing messages (i.e., diagnostic mode has to be manually re-enabled to disable signing messages).

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the time duration, in hours, that the RSU may remain in a diagnostic mode. This requirement enhances security of the V2X environment (number of unsigned messages) and reduces the likelihood of an RSU inadvertently flooding the V2X environment with unsigned messages.
The requirements to configure and monitor security for the RSU follows.
The requirements to configure and monitor security for the RSU follows.
The requirements to configure authentication for the RSU follows.

children.heading: Report Valid Geographic Region - Enrollment Certificates

discussion.comment: To distinguish from 3.5.4.1.1.2, add " - Country Code" to the end of the heading

history.addedComment: To distinguish from 3.5.4.1.1.2, add " - Country Code" to the end of the heading

history.updatedComment: To distinguish from 3.5.4.1.1.2, add " - Country Code" to the end of the heading

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the valid geographic region within which the RSU is allowed to procure enrollment certificates. Enrollment certificates may define a geographic region within which the certificate is valid. This requirement allows the RSU to report the valid geographic region by country code. The country code is defined by the United Nations M49 standard. The country code for the United States is 840. Note: the M49 standard is the same as the ISO 3166 except some countries are omitted from the M49 standard.

"enrollment certificates" is too vague. Replace with "IEEE 1609.2 enrollment certificates" or similar.

Also, the first sentence should be updated to be consistent with the remainder of the requirement. Modify the ending of the first sentence by adding "by country code".

children.heading: Report Valid Geographic Region - Enrollment Certificates – Circular Region

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the valid geographic region within which the RSU is allowed to procure enrollment certificates by country code. Enrollment certificates may define a geographic region within which the certificate is valid. This requirement allows the RSU to report the valid geographic region, which is within the radius of the RSU's location in meters, so the RSU may request, receive, and store an enrollment certificate with the appropriate geographic region.

discussion.comment:

children.text: The requirements to monitor for availability failures for the RSU follows.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the number of days before the existing enrollment certificate on the RSU expire. This requirement indicates if the RSU needs to request a new enrollment certificate. A value of 0 indicates the certificates expire that day but have not expired yet. A value of 65535 indicates the certificates have expired. A value of 65534 indicates the expiration dates are 65534 days or longer.

Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall report the number of hours before the existing application certificates on the RSU expire. This requirement indicates if the RSU needs to request new application certificates. A value of 0 indicates the certificates expire that day but have not expired yet. A value of 255 indicates the certificates have expired. A value of 254 indicates the expiration dates are 254 hours or longer.
The following defines the requirements for backward compatibility.
The following defines the requirements for backward compatibility with NTCIP 1218 v01.
Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store a message for future transmission in the NTCIP 1218 v01 format.

children.heading: NTCIP 1218 v01 - Store WSA Configuration - Secure

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall store the WSA header information in the NTCIP 1218 v01 format.
The RSU shall support the use of SHA-1 hash function (SHA) used in HMAC-SHA-96.
Note: NIST has disallowed the use of SHA-1 for digital signature generation (as provided in NIST FIPS 186-4) except where specifically allowed by NIST protocol-specific guidance.
The RSU shall support the use of SHA-2 hash function (SHA) authentication protocol. The PRL in Table 6 specifies which authentication protocol to use.
The RSU shall support the use of the Datagram Transportation Layer Security (DTLS) Protocol as a transport model following RFC 6353.

children.heading: NTCIP 1218 v01 – Support Configure Table Row

children.text: NTCIP 1218 v01 erroneously did not define a separate dialog for configuring a row in a dynamic table, particularly if the specified row did not exist. NTCIP 1218 v01A corrects this oversight by adding a new dialog, 4.2.8, Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dynamic Table. NTCIP 1218 v01A updates all requirements that configures a row in a dynamic table to point to the dialog 4.2.8 instead of dialog 4.2.3. In addition, NTCIP 1218 v01A adds support for a new object definition, rsuVerifyError, as part of dialog 4.2.8.

Supplemental non-communications requirements for RSU follow. These requirements do not directly involve communications via the communications interfaces addressed by NTCIP 1218, but, if the supplemental requirement is selected in the PRL, the implementation shall fulfill the stated requirement to claim conformance to NTCIP 1218.

Many of the security requirements (and design) for NTCIP 1218 make extensive use of the SNMPv3 security mechanisms available. This decision was made because SNMPv3 provides the most straightforward path for adoption at this time but other security mechanisms exist that may also be suitable and could be defined in future updates. For example, although NTCIP 1218 v01 specifies the use of USM and TSM below, this does not preclude the use of other security mechanisms as long as that mechanism does not conflict with the following requirements.
The requirements for the RSU to authenticate and validate messages by signing with authorized certificates.

The requirements for the RSU to maintain the confidentiality of the data exchanged with the RSU follow.
The RSU shall support the use of the User-based Security Model (USM) for SNMPv3 in accordance with RFC 3414.

discussion.comment: This is in conflict with ISO 15784-2 and is limited (i.e., it needs to specify the cipher suite to be supported). ISO 15784-2 requires TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256, which is consistent with RFC 8446 and I believe is the current recommendation of CISA

Note: This requirement was deprecated in NTCIP 1218 v01A. See Annex D.1.4 for more information.

The RSU shall process all requests in accordance with all of the rules of the referenced standards (e.g., RFC 3416), including decrypting and uncompressing the request; processing certificates, updating the value in the database; and encrypting, compressing, and initiating the transmission of the appropriate response (assuming that the RSU has permission to transmit) within the Response Time. If the specification does not indicate the Response Time, the Response Time shall be less than 1,000 milliseconds. The Response Time is measured as the time between the receiving of the last byte of the request and the transmission of the first byte of the response.

If the specification does not indicate the Response Time, the Response Time shall be less than 1,000 milliseconds. The Response Time is measured as the time between the receiving of the last byte of the request and the transmission of the first byte of the response.

For guidance, NTCIP 1103 v03 (Section 4.2.2.2) indicates the maximum response time shall be 100 milliseconds plus one millisecond for each byte in the response variable-bindings field. For testing purposes, the request consists of a single OID whose value is retrieved, e.g., rsuID.
Supplemental requirements for logging events on the RSU follow.
When a system event occurs, the RSU shall write an entry in its event log containing system messages, including errors, information messages and warnings containing the following data:
Date and Time (in UTC) of the event.

children.text: When an event changing a message received for forwarding to the V2X interface occurs, the RSU shall write an entry in its event log. The intent is to log only when the table containing the IFM messages is changed, not when the contents of the message changes. The log entry contains the following data:

attributesChanged.text:
When an event changing a message received for forwarding to the V2X interface occurs, the RSU shall write an entry in its event log. The intent is to log only when the table containing the IFM messages is changed, not when the contents of the message changes. The log entry contains the following data:

  1. Date and Time (in UTC) of the event.
  2. The message received for forwarding to the V2X interface.
  3. Classification of the operation (installation, removal, or modification).
  4. User ID of the user performing the operation.

children.text: Date and Time (in UTC) of the event.
The message received for forwarding to the V2X interface.
Classification of the operation (installation, removal, or modification).
User ID of the user performing the operation.
Requirements for the interface data logging services on the RSU follow.

children.heading: PCAP Format
children.text: Upon request from a management station, the RSU shall log interface data packets across a specified interface in the packet capture (pcap) format.

children.heading: Libpcap for Linux
children.text: Unix-based systems shall use libpcap for logging interface data packets.

children.text: Microsoft Windows-based systems shall use WinPcap for logging interface data packets.

children.text: Upon request from a management station, the interface data log file for the RSU shall contain the following data:

attributesChanged.text:
Upon request from a management station, the interface data log file for the RSU shall contain the following data:

  1. Date and Time, with minimum deci-seconds resolution, when the packet was logged, in UTC.
  2. Received Signal Strength Indication (RSSI) for packets received over the V2X interface (in units of dbm).
  3. Transmit Power for packets transmitted over the V2X interface (in units of dBm).
  4. Complete packet transmitted or received (including headers and footers).

Complete packet transmitted or received (including headers and footers).

children.text: The RSU shall have a sufficient time fix to permit a V2X radio to operate in alternating mode.

children.heading: Determine Maximum Number of Application Certificates Supported

children.text: The RSU shall contain sufficient storage space to store the Maximum Number of Application Certificates. To calculate the Maximum Number of Application Certificates needed, the deployer should consider the number of applications the RSU is expected to support, and the number of PSIDs that can be associated with an application certificate.

If the agency specification does not indicate the 'Maximum notReadyTime', the 'Maximum notReadyTime' shall be 5 minutes.

discussion.comment:
As a note, the original text failed to negate any existing requirement. Thus, the requirement of RFC 2579 still technically applied:

The agent must detect conceptual rows that have been in [the 'notInService'] state for an abnormally long period of time and remove them.... it is suggested that this period be approximately 5 minutes in length.  

In short, the note contradicted an actual requirement and therefore was wrong. I changed the note to become a proper requirement to override the RFC 2579 requirement. However, we should review the intent...

Do we wish to prohibit an implementation from ever automatically deleting the row or do we just want to define a really long minimum (e.g., shall not be deleted for at least one year).
