children.heading: Security requirements
children.text: To claim "conformance" with this document, an ESS shall only support protocols providing equivalent security to SNMPv3 per the rules of NTCIP 2301 v03. Implementations should support the communications stack defined in NTCIP 2301 v03 for the exchanged of data defined by this document.

Section 4 defines the dialogs (i.e., sequence of data exchanges) that fulfill various Data Exchange requirements defined in Section 3.5. As SNMP communications are largely driven by the management station, most of the requirements define how the device shall respond to the various possible actions a management station might take.

The NTCIP standards effort is based on SNMP. This protocol offers a high degree of flexibility as to how the management station structures its requests. For example, with SNMP, the management station can do any of the following:

attributesChanged.text:
The NTCIP standards effort is based on SNMP. This protocol offers a high degree of flexibility as to how the management station structures its requests. For example, with SNMP, the management station can do any of the following:

  1. Transmit (send) only those requests that are critical at the current time, whereas a standardized dialog typically transmits requests relating to all associated data, regardless of whether it is critical for current purposes.
  2. Combine a number of requests in a single packet, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact contents of each packet.
  3. Separate a group of requests into multiple packets, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact contents of each packet.
  4. Interweave requests from multiple dialogs, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact ordering of messages, which are not interrupted with other messages.

children.text: Transmit (send) only those requests that are critical at the current time, whereas a standardized dialog typically transmits requests relating to all associated data, regardless of whether it is critical for current purposes.
Combine a number of requests in a single packet, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact contents of each packet.
Separate a group of requests into multiple packets, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact contents of each packet.
Interweave requests from multiple dialogs, whereas a standardized dialog dictates the exact ordering of messages, which are not interrupted with other messages.

This flexibility can be a powerful tool allowing a management system to optimize the use of communication facilities, which is the primary reason that SNMP was chosen as the core NTCIP protocol. However, the flexibility also means that there are numerous allowable variations in the management process that a management station may choose to use and that an agent shall support to conform to NTCIP 1218.

Unfortunately, this flexibility presents a challenge to ensuring interoperability. While a conformant RSU is required to support all mandatory operations defined within NTCIP 1218, ensuring that a given RSU actually supports every possible combination of mandatory and optional requirements would be impractical. Instead, most agencies only require that the device be tested to a standard set of procedures, which would use standardized dialogs (as defined in Section 4.2, and Annex G). To improve communications efficiency, management stations may use non-standard dialogs (e.g., a combination of GET and/or SET requests that is not defined as a standardized dialog, but which a conformant device is required to support according to the MAX-ACCESS rules defined in Section 5). Because these more efficient dialogs may not be known until the acquisition of the management station, which may be years after the acquisition of the device, there is a potential for an interoperability problem to arise.

To overcome this complication, Section 4 defines a lowest common denominator approach to communications between a management station and a device. It defines the standardized dialog for each Data Exchange Requirement. Management stations may support other dialogs to fulfill these same requirements, as long as these dialogs are consistent with the rules defined in NTCIP 1218. Such a management station is termed a “consistent management station.” A consistent management station interoperates with any “conformant” device. However, since an agency cannot be certain that a device is 100% conformant to every possible scenario (given practical constraints), interoperability problems could still arise.

A “conformant management station” is required to offer a mode in which it only uses the standardized dialogs as defined in Section 4. With this limited definition, there is relatively little variability in what constitutes a conformant management station. Thus, fully testing a management station for conformance is a relatively straight forward process that can be done within the practical constraints faced by most procuring agencies. Thus, a conformant management station provides an agency with a much greater chance of achieving interoperability with off-the-shelf devices that have been tested against NTCIP 2104 v03, and the designation of such a system is intended to provide a guaranteed base level of interoperability.
The rules for the standardized dialogs follow:

attributesChanged.text:
The rules for the standardized dialogs follow:

  1. The dialogs are defined by a sequence of GET or SET requests. These requests shall equate to the GET and SET operations defined in Annexes G.1 and G.3 and shall be transmitted as a single message.
  2. The contents of each request are identified by an object name. Each object name consists of an object type and an instance identifier. Definitions of each object type are provided in Section 5 and NTCIP 1201 v03. The meaning of the instance identifier is provided by these same definitions coupled with standard SNMP rules (see RFC 2578).
  3. Each message shall contain all of the objects as shown, unless otherwise indicated.
  4. A message shall not contain any other objects.
  5. The contents of each message sent by the management station may appear in any order.

  7. Note: Ideally, the order of objects should match the order as shown in NTCIP 1218 to provide the highest probability of interoperability. However, it is recognized that many implementations may use off-the-shelf software, which may prevent the designation of an exact ordering of objects and as a result, this ordering is not a requirement of NTCIP 1218.

  9. After transmitting (sending) a message, the management station shall not transmit any other data to that device until the earlier of:
  10. The management station receiving a response from the device; or
  11. The expiration of the maximum response time.
  12. If the response indicates an error occurred in the operation, the management station shall exit the process, unless specific error-handling rules are specified by the dialog.
  13. Dialogs containing a sequence of only GET requests may request objects in any order.

children.text: The dialogs are defined by a sequence of GET or SET requests. These requests shall equate to the GET and SET operations defined in Annexes G.1 and G.3 and shall be transmitted as a single message.

The contents of each request are identified by an object name. Each object name consists of an object type and an instance identifier. Definitions of each object type are provided in Section 5 and NTCIP 1201 v03. The meaning of the instance identifier is provided by these same definitions coupled with standard SNMP rules (see RFC 2578).
Each message shall contain all of the objects as shown, unless otherwise indicated.
A message shall not contain any other objects.
The contents of each message sent by the management station may appear in any order.

Note: Ideally, the order of objects should match the order as shown in NTCIP 1218 to provide the highest probability of interoperability. However, it is recognized that many implementations may use off-the-shelf software, which may prevent the designation of an exact ordering of objects and as a result, this ordering is not a requirement of NTCIP 1218.
After transmitting (sending) a message, the management station shall not transmit any other data to that device until the earlier of:
The management station receiving a response from the device; or
The expiration of the maximum response time.
If the response indicates an error occurred in the operation, the management station shall exit the process, unless specific error-handling rules are specified by the dialog.
Dialogs containing a sequence of only GET requests may request objects in any order.

However, since consistent management stations can alter the order of requests, NTCIP 1218 defines rules for when certain data exchanges are allowed. Unless otherwise indicated, a conformant device shall allow an object to be retrieved (through a GET request) or altered (through a SET request, if the object is writable) at any time.
Finally, Section 4 presents an overview of all of the data defined by NTCIP 1218, prior to presenting the complete definition for each piece of data in Section 5.

The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) in Annex A.3 identifies the standardized dialog that can be used to achieve each of the data exchange requirements defined in Section 3.5. Simple data exchange requirements reference one of the generic SNMP dialogs along with a list of data elements (See Annex G). These equate to a single message being sent (e.g., a GET request) containing the referenced data elements followed by the appropriate response per the generic dialog specification.

Section 4.2 and Annex G define the standardized dialogs for the more complicated data exchange requirements. Each dialog in these sections define how the system is designed to work for a given data exchange requirement. It indicates the sequence of actions that a management station has to follow to provide the specific service. Each of these dialogs is defined by a number of steps. Many of the steps reference data elements that are defined in Section 5 or in NTCIP 1201 v03. These data elements are also shown in the corresponding row of the RTM along with their precise section number.

The dialogs may also be accompanied by an informative figure that provides a graphical depiction of the normative text. The figures conform to the Unified Modeling Language and depict the management station as an outside actor transmitting (sending) a series of messages to the device and the device returning responses. If there is any conflict between the figure and the text, the text takes precedence.

This section provides the standardized data exchange sequences that can be used by management stations to ensure interoperable implementations for the various data exchange requirements identified in Section 3. Diagrams and graphical representations are included to supplement the text (i.e., not used as a replacement for the text). This section only includes dialogs that have special semantics or impose special restrictions on the operations that are allowed.

children.heading: Generic Retrieve Table Dialog - Static Table

children.text: Note: This is a generic dialog that is referenced by requirements in the RTM with specific object names in a static table. This generic dialog does NOT supersede the requirements and mechanism of the Block Object management defined in NTCIP 1201 v03, Section 2.3 and Annex A.1.
The list of objects provided by the specific dialog shall include the following:

attributesChanged.text:
The list of objects provided by the specific dialog shall include the following:

  1. An object that indicates the number of rows in the table,
  2. The object(s) that serve as the index field of the table row, and
  3. The list of columnar objects to be retrieved from the table.

children.text: An object that indicates the number of rows in the table,
The object(s) that serve as the index field of the table row, and
The list of columnar objects to be retrieved from the table.
The standardized dialog for a management station to retrieve a table shall be as follows:

attributesChanged.text:
The standardized dialog for a management station to retrieve a table shall be as follows:

  1. The management station shall GET the number of rows in the table.
  2. For each row of the table, the management station shall GET all objects referenced by the specific dialog that references this generic dialog, except for the number of rows object and the index object(s).

children.text: The management station shall GET the number of rows in the table.

For each row of the table, the management station shall GET all objects referenced by the specific dialog that references this generic dialog, except for the number of rows object and the index object(s).
For example, the standardized dialog for a management station to identify the hardware and software configuration of a NTCIP device would be as follows:

  1. The management station shall GET the object globalMaxModules.0.
  2. For each row in the module table, the management station shall GET the following objects:

children.text: The management station shall GET the object globalMaxModules.0.
For each row in the module table, the management station shall GET the following objects:
1)     moduleDeviceNode.x,
2)     moduleMake.x,
3)     moduleModel.x,
4)     moduleVersion.x,
5)     moduleType.x.

Where:
     x = module number

children.heading: Generic Retrieve Table Dialog - Dynamic Table

children.text: Note: This is a generic dialog that is referenced by requirements in the RTM with specific object names in a dynamic table. This generic dialog does NOT supersede the requirements and mechanism of the Block Object management defined in NTCIP 1201 v03, Section 2.3 and Annex A.1.

  1. The object(s) that serve as the index field of the table row, and

children.text: The object(s) that serve as the index field of the table row, and
The list of columnar objects to be retrieved from the table.
The standardized dialog for a management station to retrieve a table shall be as follows:

The management station shall perform GET-NEXT on all objects in the table referenced by the specific dialog that references this generic dialog, except for the index object(s), starting with the table OID and ending once all objects in the table have been returned.

Note: This is a generic dialog that is referenced by requirements in the RTM with a specific object name that either contains the name of a file to be copied or contains the directory with the files to be copied.
The device shall adhere to the following rules:

attributesChanged.text:
The device shall adhere to the following rules:

  1. If the object points to a directory path, that directory path is the base directory and a user cannot traverse to any parent directory.
  2. If the object points to a directory path, subdirectories that are not links may be used.

children.text: If the object points to a directory path, that directory path is the base directory and a user cannot traverse to any parent directory.
If the object points to a directory path, subdirectories that are not links may be used.

This dialog is used to install firmware updates, applications, or component updates on the RSU. This dialog allows an agency to copy an installation file to the RSU, identify the location and name of the installation file, start a process to install the necessary components on the RSU, then confirm that the installation was properly completed. The installation file for the RSU is analogous to an installation file in Microsoft Windows. NTCIP 1218 does not identify the format of the installation file nor does it define how the installation process works. The installation process also should consider the authentication and integrity of the installation file, and any encryption that may be used in compliance with the appropriate agency policies.
The standardized dialog for a management station to install new software components on the RSU shall be as follows:

attributesChanged.text:
The standardized dialog for a management station to install new software components on the RSU shall be as follows:

  1. (Preconditions) The software installation package shall contain all the necessary components to be installed.
  2. (Preconditions) The management station shall be aware of the filename of the source file containing the package to be installed on the RSU.
  3. The management station shall GET rsuInstallPath to identify the target directory of where the installation file is copied to.
  4. The management station shall SET rsuInstallFile to identify the target filename of the package to be installed on the RSU.
  5. The management station copy the source file to the target directory and filename using 4.2.5 Secure Copy Protocol Dialog.
  6. The management station shall SET rsuInstallUpdate to 'TRUE' to begin the installation.
  7. The management station shall GET rsuInstallStatus.
  8. If the response is 'processing' the RSU is processing the installation of the package. The management station shall continue to GET rsuInstallStatus until the response is any other value than 'processing.'
  9. If the response is 'rejected' or 'rollback,' the RSU has encountered an error and the management station shall exit this process and determine the source of the error.
  10. No guidance is provided if the response is 'other' or'unknown.' A response of 'other' generally indicates a vendor-specific error.
  11. If the response is 'successful,' the installation process is complete and the management station shall either GET the rsuFirmwareVersion or GET the contents of the globalModuleTable to confirm the module and firmware version information has been properly updated. The RSU shall then exit this process.

children.text: (Preconditions) The software installation package shall contain all the necessary components to be installed.
(Preconditions) The management station shall be aware of the filename of the source file containing the package to be installed on the RSU.
The management station shall GET rsuInstallPath to identify the target directory of where the installation file is copied to.
The management station shall SET rsuInstallFile to identify the target filename of the package to be installed on the RSU.
The management station copy the source file to the target directory and filename using 4.2.5 Secure Copy Protocol Dialog.
The management station shall SET rsuInstallUpdate to 'TRUE' to begin the installation.
The management station shall GET rsuInstallStatus.

If the response is 'processing' the RSU is processing the installation of the package. The management station shall continue to GET rsuInstallStatus until the response is any other value than 'processing.'
If the response is 'rejected' or 'rollback,' the RSU has encountered an error and the management station shall exit this process and determine the source of the error.
No guidance is provided if the response is 'other' or'unknown.' A response of 'other' generally indicates a vendor-specific error.

If the response is 'successful,' the installation process is complete and the management station shall either GET the rsuFirmwareVersion or GET the contents of the globalModuleTable to confirm the module and firmware version information has been properly updated. The RSU shall then exit this process.

This dialog allows a transportation operator to generate and download a copy of the logged event data in the RSU's system log (syslog) file. NTCIP 1218 allows the transportation operator to filter the logged event data in the copy of the syslog file by (start and stop) time and severity.
The standardized dialog for a management station to retrieve logged data from the RSU's system log shall be as follows:

attributesChanged.text:
The standardized dialog for a management station to retrieve logged data from the RSU's system log shall be as follows:

  1. The management station shall SET rsuSysLogQueryStart, rsuSysLogQueryStop, and rsuSysLogQueryPriority.
  2. The management station shall SET rsuSysLogQueryGenerate to '1.'
  3. The RSU shall create a copy of the syslog file using the values in rsuSysLogQueryStart, rsuSysLogQueryStop, and rsuSysLogQueryPriority to filter the events.
  4. The management station shall GET rsuSysLogQueryStatus.
  5. If the response is 'processing' the RSU is processing the logged event data. The management station shall continue to GET rsuSysLogQueryStatus until the response is any other value than 'processing.'
  6. If the response is 'outOfRange' or 'badFilename,' the RSU has encountered an error and the management station shall exit this process and determine the source of the error.
  7. No guidance is provided if the response is 'other' or 'unknown.' A response of 'other' generally indicates a vendor-specific error.
  8. If the response is 'successful,' the installation process is complete and the management station shall download the copy of the syslog file from the RSU using the Secure Copy Protocol Dialog (See Section 4.2.5). The value of the rsuSysLogName contains the directory and filename of the copy of the syslog file, relative to the base directory, which is provided by rsuSysDir. The management station shall then exit this process.
The standardized dialog for a management station to retrieve logged data from the RSU's system log shall be as follows:

children.text: The management station shall SET rsuSysLogQueryStart, rsuSysLogQueryStop, and rsuSysLogQueryPriority.
The management station shall SET rsuSysLogQueryGenerate to '1.'
The RSU shall create a copy of the syslog file using the values in rsuSysLogQueryStart, rsuSysLogQueryStop, and rsuSysLogQueryPriority to filter the events.
The management station shall GET rsuSysLogQueryStatus.
If the response is 'processing' the RSU is processing the logged event data. The management station shall continue to GET rsuSysLogQueryStatus until the response is any other value than 'processing.'
If the response is 'outOfRange' or 'badFilename,' the RSU has encountered an error and the management station shall exit this process and determine the source of the error.
No guidance is provided if the response is 'other' or 'unknown.' A response of 'other' generally indicates a vendor-specific error.

If the response is 'successful,' the installation process is complete and the management station shall download the copy of the syslog file from the RSU using the Secure Copy Protocol Dialog (See Section 4.2.5). The value of the rsuSysLogName contains the directory and filename of the copy of the syslog file, relative to the base directory, which is provided by rsuSysDir. The management station shall then exit this process.

children.heading: Generic Configure Table Row Dialog – Dynamic Table

children.text: Note: This is a generic dialog that is referenced by other dialogs with specific object names.

The list of objects provided by the specific dialog shall include the following:

  1. The object(s) that serve as the index field of the table row, and
  2. The list of columnar objects to be configured and their desired values.
The standardized dialog for a management station to configure a table row in a dynamic table shall be as follows:

attributesChanged.text:
The standardized dialog for a management station to configure a table row in a dynamic table shall be as follows:

  1. (Precondition) The management station shall be aware of which row in the table is to be configured.
  2. For the specified row, the management station shall SET all objects (to their desired values) referenced by the specific dialog that references this generic dialog, except for the index object(s), in a single request.
    1. For the specified row, if the current value of status column (before sending the SET request) is 'notReady(3)' OR if the specified row does not exist, then SET the status column to createAndGo(4) as part of the single request.
  3. The RSU may initiate a consistency check to analyze the objects 'in context' treating them as an interrelated values rather than separate non-related data items, and that the values are valid.
  4. If the consistency check is successfully completed AND if the SET request contains a desired value of active(1) or createAndGo(4) for the status column, the RSU shall change the value of status column to active(1). Exit the process.
  5. If the consistency check is successfully completed AND if the SET request contains a desired value of notInService(2) or createAndWait(5) for the status column, the RSU shall change the value of status column to notInService(2). Exit the process.
  6. If the consistency check is not completed successfully, the RSU shall change the value of status column to notReady(3). The management station shall GET the 'rsuVerifyError' object to determine the error with the consistency check.

children.text: (Precondition) The management station shall be aware of which row in the table is to be configured.

For the specified row, the management station shall SET all objects (to their desired values) referenced by the specific dialog that references this generic dialog, except for the index object(s), in a single request.

children.text: For the specified row, if the current value of status column (before sending the SET request) is 'notReady(3)' OR if the specified row does not exist, then SET the status column to createAndGo(4) as part of the single request.
The RSU may initiate a consistency check to analyze the objects 'in context' treating them as an interrelated values rather than separate non-related data items, and that the values are valid.

If the consistency check is successfully completed AND if the SET request contains a desired value of active(1) or createAndGo(4) for the status column, the RSU shall change the value of status column to active(1). Exit the process.

If the consistency check is successfully completed AND if the SET request contains a desired value of notInService(2) or createAndWait(5) for the status column, the RSU shall change the value of status column to notInService(2). Exit the process.

If the consistency check is not completed successfully, the RSU shall change the value of status column to notReady(3). The management station shall GET the 'rsuVerifyError' object to determine the error with the consistency check.

children.heading: Generic Delete Table Row Dialog – Dynamic Table

children.text: The standardized dialog for a management station to delete a table row in a dynamic table shall be as follows:

attributesChanged.text:
The standardized dialog for a management station to delete a table row in a dynamic table shall be as follows:

  1. (Precondition) The management station shall be aware of which row in the table is to be deleted.
  2. For the specified row, the management station shall SET the status column to destroy(6).

children.text: (Precondition) The management station shall be aware of which row in the table is to be deleted.
For the specified row, the management station shall SET the status column to destroy(6).

State-Transition diagrams are included for those objects that have states or manage states. The State Transition Diagrams include state-transition tables (listing of the possible state transitions), legitimate transitions, and any illegitimate transitions.

"State-transition diagrams describe all of the states that an object can have, the events under which an object changes state (transitions), the conditions that must be fulfilled before the transition will occur (guards), and the activities undertaken during the life of an object (actions)." (See State-Transition Diagrams: Testing UML Models, Part 4, Copeland, Lee)
Definitions of the states for various object classes that may be supported by the RSU follow.
The RSU shall allow a management station to manage the mode of operation of the RSU.
When in the 'operating' mode, the following rules shall apply to the RSU:

attributesChanged.text:
When in the 'operating' mode, the following rules shall apply to the RSU:

  1. If rsuMode is SET to 'standby,' the RSU shall transfer to the Standby mode.
  2. Any V2X radio may be enabled (to transmit or receive).
  3. Interface logging may be enabled.

children.text: If rsuMode is SET to 'standby,' the RSU shall transfer to the Standby mode.
Any V2X radio may be enabled (to transmit or receive).
Interface logging may be enabled.
When in the 'standby' mode, the following rules shall apply to the RSU:

attributesChanged.text:
When in the 'standby' mode, the following rules shall apply to the RSU:

  1. If rsuMode is SET to 'operate,' the RSU shall transfer to the Operating mode.
  2. All V2X radios are not enabled (to transmit or receive).
  3. All interface logging is disabled.
  4. The RSU shall return a 'genErr' error for any SET to enable a V2X radio.
  5. The RSU shall return a 'genErr' error for any SET to enable interface logging.

children.text: If rsuMode is SET to 'operate,' the RSU shall transfer to the Operating mode.
All V2X radios are not enabled (to transmit or receive).
All interface logging is disabled.
The RSU shall return a 'genErr' error for any SET to enable a V2X radio.
The RSU shall return a 'genErr' error for any SET to enable interface logging.
When in the 'fault' mode, the following rules shall apply to the RSU:

attributesChanged.text:
When in the 'fault' mode, the following rules shall apply to the RSU:

  1. The RSU shall return a 'genErr' error for any SET request from a management station EXCEPT to download and install new firmware or application version. See Dialog 4.2.6.
  2. All V2X radios are not enabled (to transmit or receive).
  3. All interface logging is disabled.

children.text: The RSU shall return a 'genErr' error for any SET request from a management station EXCEPT to download and install new firmware or application version. See Dialog 4.2.6.
All V2X radios are not enabled (to transmit or receive).
All interface logging is disabled.

children.text: Section 5 defines those objects that are specifically used by RSUs. The objects are defined using the OBJECT-TYPE macro as specified in RFCs 2578, 2579, and 2580. The text provided in Section 5 (except the section headings) constitutes the standard NTCIP1218-v01 MIB.

All of the objects defined in NTCIP 1218 reside under the “rsu” node of the global naming tree. To aid in object management, the “rsu” node has been subdivided into logical categories, each defined by a node under the “rsu” node. The individual objects are then located under the appropriate node.

Conformance requirements for any object are determined by the use of the Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) in Annex A. To support any defined Requirement, an implementation shall support all objects to which the Requirement traces in the RTM. The value of the STATUS field for every object in the MIB is "mandatory," and indicates that it is mandatory if any associated Requirement is selected.
For all bitmapped objects, if a bit is zero (0), then the referenced function is disabled or not supported, and if a bit is one (1), then the referenced function is enabled or supported.

A computer readable format of this information, called a Management Information Base, is available from NEMA (ntcip@nema.org). The MIB has been verified using Unbrowse SNMP version 1.6.0.1342 (https://www.unleashnetworks.com/products/unbrowse-snmp.html) and SMI SNMP Validator based on libsmi (smilint 0.4.7) (https://www.simpleweb.org/ietf/mibs/validate/).

children.text: A valid range of values for use in table indices
children.name: RsuTableIndex

children.text:
PSID associated with a SAE J2735 message. The PSID is formatted per IEEE1609.3 as P-encoded values, e.g. BSM = 0x20, TIM = 0x8003, WSA = 0x8007, IProuting = 0xEFFFFFFE. For those PSIDs less than 4 octets in length, the RSU should only require the significant octets be provided. For example, if the desired PSID is 0x20, then the RSU should accept a supplied value of 0x20. It should not need to be padded to a 4-octet length.

A PSID of 0x00 may be used as a wildcard to represent ANY PSID value, such as when used as a filter, if specified by the object definition.

children.heading: RSU Radio Enable
children.text:
<Definition> Indicates the enabled state of the V2X radio. A value of 1 indicates that the radio is enabled for transmission and reception; a value of 0 indicates that the radio is disabled. This is a global switch to enable / disable the V2X radio.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.3

children.heading: RSU Radio Type
children.text:
<Definition> Indicates the type of V2X Radio. pC5 is LTE-V2X.

<Format> 

value    meaning

other    The radio conforms to a format other than those specified in this enumeration

dsrc      The radio shall support DSRC communications as defined by IEEE 802.11 and the Federal Communications Commission

pc5       The radio shall support DSRC communications as defined by ETSI TS 136 213, ETSI TS 136 321, and ETSI TS 136 322.

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.4

children.heading: RSU Radio MAC Address 1
children.text:
<Definition> Represents an 802 MAC address of the V2X Radio represented in the 'canonical' order defined by IEEE 802.1a, i.e., as if it were transmitted least significant bit first, even though 802.5 (in contrast to other 802.x protocols) requires MAC addresses to be transmitted most significant bit first. For a PC5 radio, use the least significant 24-bit for the MAC address (Layer 2 Source id). If the MacAddress is not available, set the MacAddress to all ones (1).
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.5
children.name: rsuRadioMacAddress1

children.heading: RSU Radio MAC Address 2
children.text:
<Definition> Represents the second IEEE 802 MAC address of the V2X Radio operating on a channel switch. The MAC address is as if the represented in the 'canonical' order defined by IEEE 802.1a, i.e., as if it were transmitted least significant bit first, even though 802.5 (in contrast to other 802.x protocols) requires MAC addresses to be transmitted most significant bit first. If the MacAddress is not available or if the radio doesn't have a second MAC, set the MacAddress to all ones (1).
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.6
children.name: rsuRadioMacAddress2

children.heading: RSU Radio Channel Mode
children.text:
<Definition> Represents the channel access mode for the radio. Supported values are continuous access (cont), alternating access (alt), and immediate access as defined in IEEE 1609.3. A SET to a value of other (1) or unknown (2) shall return a badValue error. Use cont (3) for LTE-V2X radio.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.7
children.name: rsuRadioChanMode

children.heading: RSU Radio Channel 1
children.text:
<Definition> Represents the channel number for continuous mode as well as for time slot 0 when the radio is operating in alternating mode. For PC5 radios in the United States, the relationship between IEEE 802.11 and 3GPP channel numbers is found in Table 7 of NTCIP 1218.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.8
children.name: rsuRadioCh1

children.heading: RSU Radio Channel 2
children.text:
<Definition> Represents the channel number for channel slot 2. For PC5 radios in the United States, the relationship between IEEE 802.11 and 3GPP channel numbers is found in Table 7 of NTCIP 1218. If the radio operates in continuous mode, this value is equal to rsuRadioCh1 and is ignored.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.9
children.name: rsuRadioCh2

children.heading: RSU Radio Channel 1 - Default Transmit Power
children.text:
<Definition> Sets the output power for channel slot 1, in dBm, at the V2X antenna port. This object is considered a default transmit power level to be used if a power level is not defined by an application. The power level defined by the application would take precedence.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.10
children.name: rsuRadioTxPower1

children.heading: RSU Radio Channel 2 - Default Transmit Power
children.text:
<Definition> Sets the output power for channel slot 2, in dBm, at the V2X antenna port. This object is considered a default transmit power level to be used if a power level is not defined by an application. The power level defined by the application would take precedence. If the radio operates in continuous mode, this value is equal to rsuRadioTxPower1 and is ignored.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.1.2.1.11
children.name: rsuRadioTxPower2

discussion.comment:
Do we need a max object and what is its purpose? Specifically, is the intent to:

  1. Require all entries to be sequentially numbered (in which case, the table needs to be static to prevent rows from being deleted and thereby causing a gap in the sequence)
  2. Limit the number of rows in the table (i.e., reject any request to create a new row once the maximum number is reached; perhaps to limit processing requirements imposed by the table) but allow the identifiers to be any positive Integer32 value (in which case, we need to change the definition for index object to allow the range defined by its SYNTAX) or
  3. Limit the number of rows in this table and require the rows to be assigned IDs within that same range (why?) (in which case we should further constrain the SYNTAX of the index object to match the max object)

Do we need an objet to allow a management station to quickly determine an available entry in the table, for example, an "availableID" parameter that allows a management station to identify an appropriate identifier to use. If we want an availableID object, should it always increment to the next unused number when read so that managers do not end up in race conditions when configuring a device.

Typ. for all max objects

history.updatedComment:
Do we need a max object and what is its purpose (i.e., rows do not have to be sequential as implied by the index having a much larger range than the max object)? Would it be better to have a next object? i.e., when the management station wants to create a new row in the table, it needs to be able to determine an available entry. We could provide a "availableID" parameter that allows a management station to identify an appropriate identifier to use. If we want an availableID object, should it always increment to the next unused number when read so that managers do not end up in race conditions when configuring a device.

Typ. for all max objects

children.heading: Stored Message Start Time
children.text:
<Definition> Store and Repeat Message delivery start time in UTC. DateAndTime of length 8 octets. If a user attempts to SET this object to time that has already passed, the value of this object shall be equal to the date the current time (that this object was SET). For example, if a user attempts to SET this object to January 1 2023 12:00:00.0 (07 D6 01 01 0C 00 00 00), but the current time is February 1 2023 00:00:00.0 (07 D6 02 01 00 00 00 00), then this object will be SET to 07 D6 02 01 00 00 00 00.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.2.1.5
children.name: rsuMsgRepeatDeliveryStart

children.heading: Stored Message Stop Time
children.text:

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.2.1.6
children.name: rsuMsgRepeatDeliveryStop

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.2.1.7

history.addedComment: What is the difference between 1) setting enabled to off and 2) setting status to notInService. It seems as if the enabled object is redundant and should be deprecated

history.deleteLastComment: What is the difference between 1) setting enabled to off and 2) setting status to notInService. It seems as if the enabled object is redundant and should be deprecated

children.heading: Stored Message Status
children.text:
<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for the objects contained in the corresponding row.

Recommended practice: The values for a row in the rsuMsgRepeatPsid, rsuMsgRepeatTxChannel, rsuMsgRepeatTxInterval, rsuMsgRepeatPayload, rsuMsgRepeatPriority, and rsuMsgRepeatOptions, rsuMsgRepeatPayload2 columns cannot be edited while rsuMsgRepeatStatus is 'active (1)' and rsuMsgRepeatEnable = 'on (1)'.

When this object has a value of 'active', an implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuMsgRepeatDeliveryStart, rsuMsgRepeatDeliveryStop, rsuMsgRepeatEnable, and this object for the corresponding row and should reject any request to modify any other object in the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while rsuMsgRepeatEnable has a value of 'on' (1).

See Requirement 3.6.9 and 3.6.10 in the PRL for performance requirements.

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.2.1.9
children.name: rsuMsgRepeatStatus

discussion.comment: Revised the text to specify (1) the algorithm that a command generator should use to select an index for a new row in the table, (2) conditions that will cause the row to be considered 'notReady', (3) whether support for the notInService state is required/optional/prohibited, (4) which if any columns can only be changed when the row is not in the active state, (5) whether createAndWait actions are required, optional, or prohibited, and (6) how long a conceptual row can remain within the notReady or notInService state prior to the agent being required to automatically delete the row (RFC 2579 recommends 5 minutes as a default).

Unclear why notInService is required while createAndWait is not required

Typ. for all RowStatus Objects
Removed RsuPsidTC from list of objects because it is not an object

With original design, it is unclear why there is an enabled object, if I can leave in notInService for a prolonged time. However, with the refinement, the Enabled switch allows the user to disable broadcasts so that the command to the notInService mode can be reliably performed and then values changed.


Typ. for all RowStatus objects.

history.addedComment: Revise the text for each RowStatus object to specify (1) the algorithgm that a command generator should use to select an index for a new row in the table, (2) conditions that will cause the row to be considered 'notReady', (3) whether support for the notInService state is required/optional/prohibited (and why it might be used), (4) which if any columns can only be changed when the row is not in the active state, (5) whether createAndWait actions are required, optional, or prohibited (note: not supporting this value results in each row becoming active upon creation), and (6) how long a conceptual row can remain within the notReady or notInService state prior to the agent being required to automatically delete the row (RFC 2579 recommends 5 minutes as a default).

history.updatedComment:
Unclear why notInService is required while createAndWait is not required

Typ. for all RowStatus Objects

<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for the objects contained in the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to modify the Recommended practice: The values of for a row in the rsuMsgRepeatPsid, rsuMsgRepeatTxChannel, rsuMsgRepeatTxInterval, rsuMsgRepeatPayload, rsuMsgRepeatPriority, or and rsuMsgRepeatOptions when columns cannot be edited while rsuMsgRepeatStatus is 'active (1)' for the corresponding row and rsuMsgRepeatEnable = 'on (1)'.

An implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuMsgRepeatDeliveryStart, rsuMsgRepeatDeliveryStart, and this object when rsuMsgRepeatStatus is 'active' for the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while a transmission corresponding to this row is in progress.

See Requirement 3.6.9 in the PRL for performance requirements.

history.updatedComment: Revise the text for each RowStatus object to specify (1) the algorithgm that a command generator should use to select an index for a new row in the table, (2) conditions that will cause the row to be considered 'notReady', (3) whether support for the notInService state is required/optional/prohibited (and why it might be used), (4) which if any columns can only be changed when the row is not in the active state, (5) whether createAndWait actions are required, optional, or prohibited (note: not supporting this value results in each row becoming active upon creation), and (6) how long a conceptual row can remain within the notReady or notInService state prior to the agent being required to automatically delete the row (RFC 2579 recommends 5 minutes as a default).

children.heading: Stored Message Priority
children.text:
<Definition> Priority assigned to the Store and Repeat message. Priority values are defined by IEEE 1609.3.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.2.1.10
children.name: rsuMsgRepeatPriority

children.heading: Stored Message Options
children.text:
<Definition> A bit-mapped value as defined below for configuring the message.
Bit 0 0=Bypass1609.2, 1=Process1609.2
Bit 1 0=Secure, 1=Unsecure
Bit 2 0=ContXmit, 1=NoXmitShortTermXceeded
Bit 3 0=ContXmit, 1=NoXmitLongTermXceeded

Bit 0 - Indicates if the RSU is to bypass 1609.2 processing of the message to the V2X interface. This allows the RSU to send the message that has been signed and/or encrypted by the TMC. Note the RSU would still wrap the message payload in a WSMP header.
Bit 1 - Indicates if the message should be secured (signed or encrypted) prior to transmission to the V2X Interface. How the message is to be secured is determined by its security profile for that PSID. This bit is ignored if Bit 0=0 (bypass).
Bit 2 - Indicates if the message should continue to be transmitted if the short-term communications loss period (rsuShortCommLossTime) is exceeded. 0 indicates the message should continue to be transmitted. Default value is 0.
Bit 3 - Indicates if the message should continue to be transmitted if the long-term communications loss period (rsuLongCommLossTime) is exceeded. 0 indicates the message should continue to be transmitted unless Bit 2 is a value of 1, which indicates the message has stopped transmitting after short-term communications loss period (rsuShortCommLossTime) is exceeded. Default value is 0.
See Section 2.5 of RFC 3416 for encoding.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.2.1.11
children.name: rsuMsgRepeatOptions

discussion.comment: for bit 1, "determined by its security profile" is ambiguous. Based on the response to the previous comment, I propose that the correct text should be "determined by the 1609.2 security services based on the security profile defined for the PSID"

history.addedComment: for bit 1, "determined by its security profile" is ambiguous. Based on the response to the previous comment, I propose that the correct text should be "determined by the 1609.2 security services based on the security profile defined for the PSID"

children.heading: Stored Message Payload2
children.text:
<Definition> Payload of Store and Repeat message. Length limit is derived from SAE J3161. For SAE J2735 messages, this object is the UPER encoded MessageFrame. The size of the Signed WSMP message, including the WSMP header, and the 1 Byte non-IP LLC byte must be 4214 or less. Packets 4215 or larger should actually be dropped/not-transmitted by the RSU.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.2.1.12
children.name: rsuMsgRepeatPayload2

children.heading: Delete All Stored Messages
children.text:
<Definition> This object when set to TRUE (one) shall cause the Roadside Unit to delete (destroy) all stored messages in the rsuMsgRepeatStatusTable. This object shall automatically return to FALSE (zero) after all rows in the rsuMsgRepeatStatusTable have been deleted.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.3.3
children.name: rsuMsgRepeatDeleteAll

children.heading: Immediate Forward Messages
children.text:
<Definition> A node containing information about messages to be immediately forwarded by the RSU to a V2X link.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4
children.name: rsuIFM

discussion.comment:
The user need that this was based on asked for immediate forwarding (i.e., send a message to a specified port number and the RSU would forward the contents to the V2X network per a set of rules, perhaps with other features such as recording the payload of the last message in an object). This design morphed it into an "application layer broadcast". i.e., the management station sets an SNMP payload object and directs the RSU to send to the V2X interface per a set of rules. However, those rules do not specify exactly when it is broadcasted and Bits 2 & 3 in the Options parameter imply that it is repeatedly broadcast (at some unknown rate, perhaps continuously).

Do we want to 1) redesign this capability to conform with the stated user need, 2) revise the user need to more closely resemble the design and revise the design to address ambiguities? Is there any case where Bits 2 and 3 apply to this capability?

history.addedComment: This would be clearer if we used formal terminology. In other words, rather than describing this as "message forwarding", we should be talking about application layer gateway functionality (which is a specific type of message forwarding)

history.editLastComment: This would be clearer if we used formal terminology. In other words, rather than describing this as "message forwarding", we should be talking about application layer gateway functionality (which is a specific type of message forwarding)

This would be clearer if we used formal terminology. In other words, rather than describing this as "message forwarding", which strongly implies network layer functionality, we should be talking about "application layer gateway" or "application layer broadcast" functionality (which is a specific type of message forwarding)

This would be clearer if we used formal terminology. In other words, rather than describing this as "message forwarding", which strongly implies network layer functionality, we should be talking about "application layer gateway" (if it is to a specific address)or "application layer broadcast" (all listeners) functionality

history.updatedComment: This would be clearer if we used formal terminology. In other words, rather than describing this as "message forwarding", which strongly implies network layer functionality, we should be as precise as possible; I think the intent is "application layer broadcast". i.e., we are providing a message to the RSU that we want to be broadcast to its subnet according to the configured management parameters.

children.heading: Maximum Number of Immediate Forward Messages
children.text:
<Definition> The maximum number of Immediate Forward messages this Roadside Unit supports. This object indicates the maximum rows which appears in the rsuIFMStatusTable object.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.1
children.name: maxRsuIFMs

history.removedComment: Do we need a max object, what is its purpose (i.e., rows do not have to be sequential)? Would it be better to have a next object? i.e., when the management station wants to create a new row in the table, it needs to be able to determine an available entry. We could provide a "availableID" parameter that allows a management station to identify an appropriate identifier to use

children.heading: Immediate Forward Table
children.text:
<Definition> Provides configuration parameters for each Immediate Forward message sent by a Roadside Unit.

<TableType> managed

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2
children.name: rsuIFMStatusTable

discussion.comment: Does this table need to support multiple managers?
Changed to "managed" table type to conform to NTCIP 8004

Should this table be stored in volatile or nonVolatile memory or should it be configurable?

Are there any permanent (which columns are writable) or read-only rows in the table?

attributesChanged.text:

<TableType> dynamic

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1
children.name: rsuIFMStatusEntry
RsuIFMStatusEntry

{
    rsuIFMIndex             RsuTableIndex,

    rsuIFMOptions           BITS,

children.heading: Forward Message Index
children.text:
<Definition> Immediate Forward Message Index. This index shall not exceed maxRsuIFMs.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1.1
children.name: rsuIFMIndex

history.addedComment: Syntax inconsistent with maxRows object

history.updatedComment: Syntax inconsistent with maxRows object

history.removedComment: Revised syntax to be consistent with definition.

children.heading: Forward Message PSID
children.text:
<Definition> The Provider Service Identifier (PSID) of the message to be forwarded. The current PSID assignments can be found at https://standards.ieee.org/products-services/regauth/psid/public/.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1.2
children.name: rsuIFMPsid

children.heading: Forward Message Transmission Channel
children.text:
<Definition> The transmission channel the Immediate Forward Message is to be transmitted. For DSRC radios in the United States, the transmission channel is from 180 to 184, as defined by IEEE 802.11. For PC5 radios in the United States, the channel number is found in Table 7 of NTCIP 1218 v01.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1.3
children.name: rsuIFMTxChannel

children.heading: Forward Message Enable
children.text:
<Definition> Set this bit to enable transmission of the message. 1 is to enable transmission.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1.4
children.name: rsuIFMEnable

children.heading: Forward Message Status
children.text:
<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for all objects contained in the corresponding row.

When this object has a value of 'active', an implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuIFMEnable and this object for the corresponding row and should reject any request to modify any other object in the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while rsuIFMEnable for the corresponding row has a value of 'on' (1).

See Requirement 3.6.9 and 3.6.10 in the PRL for performance requirements.


<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1.5
children.name: rsuIFMStatus

discussion.comment: Deleted RsuPsidTC from the list of objects in the recommended practice because it is a Textual Convention, not an object, and therefore does not have a value (i.e., it is a datatype).

Revised the text to specify (1) the algorithm that a command generator should use to select an index for a new row in the table, (2) conditions that will cause the row to be considered 'notReady', (3) whether support for the notInService state is required/optional/prohibited, (4) which if any columns can only be changed when the row is not in the active state, (5) whether createAndWait actions are required, optional, or prohibited, and (6) how long a conceptual row can remain within the notReady or notInService state prior to the agent being required to automatically delete the row (RFC 2579 recommends 5 minutes as a default).

children.heading: Forward Message Priority
children.text:
<Definition> Priority assigned to the Immediate Forward message. Priority values defined by IEEE 1609.3.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1.6
children.name: rsuIFMPriority

children.heading: Forward Message Options
children.text:
<Definition> A bit-mapped value as defined below for configuring the message.

Bit 0 0=Bypass1609.2, 1=Process1609.2

Bit 1 0=Secure, 1=Unsecure

Bit 2 0=ContXmit, 1=NoXmitShortTermXceeded

Bit 3 0=ContXmit, 1=NoXmitLongTermXceeded


Bit 0 - Indicates if the RSU is to bypass 1609.2 processing of the message to the V2X interface. This allows the RSU to send the message that has been signed and/or encrypted by the TMC. Note the RSU would still wrap the message payload in a WSMP header.

Bit 1 - Indicates if the message should be secured (signed or encrypted) prior to transmission to the V2X Interface. How the message is to be secured is determined by its security profile. This bit is ignored if Bit 0=0 (bypass).

Bit 2 - Indicates if the message should continue to be transmitted if the short-term communications loss period (rsuShortCommLossTime) is exceeded. 0 indicates the message should continue to be transmitted. Default value is 0.

Bit 3 - Indicates if the message should continue to be transmitted if the long-term communications loss period (rsuLongCommLossTime) is exceeded unless Bit 2 is a value of 1, which indicates the message has stopped transmitting after short-term communications loss period (rsuShortCommLossTime) is exceeded. 0 indicates the message should continue to be transmitted. Default value is 0.

See Section 2.5 of RFC 3416 for encoding.

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.4.2.1.7
children.name: rsuIFMOptions

discussion.comment: If we are immediately forwarding the message (i.e., a single time), it is unclear what Bits 2 and 3 mean.

history.addedComment: If we are not talking about application layer broadcasting, it is unclear what Bits 2 and 3 mean

history.editLastComment: If we are not talking about application layer broadcasting, it is unclear what Bits 2 and 3 mean

See Section 2.5 of RFC 3416 for encoding.

history.updatedComment: If we are immediately forwarding the message, it is unclear what Bits 2 and 3 mean. This is why I think the intent is application layer broadcasting.

children.text:
<Definition> Destination Server IP address to forward the message received by the RSU over the V2X Interface. For an IPv4 remote destination, this address can be represented as an IPv4 quad-dotted IP address, for example, 192.33.44.235. For IPv6 remote destination, this address can be represented as zero-compressed simplified IPv6 address, for example 2031:0:130F::9C0:876A:130B.

children.heading: Received Message Destination Protocol
children.text:
<Definition> Transport Protocol between RSU and Server to forward the message received by the RSU over the V2X Interface. The entire WSMP payload, including certificates and signature unless indicated by the rsuReceivedMsgSecure object, are to be forwarded.

If udp is selected, the message contains the binary data (payload) defined by rsuReceivedMsgSecure.

A SET to a value of 'other' shall return a badValue error.

NOTE: If other is selected, this object allows for future extensions, possibly tcp.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.5
children.name: rsuReceivedMsgProtocol

children.heading: Received Message Minimum Signal Strength
children.text:
<Definition> Minimum Received Signal Strength Level (in dbm units) of the SAE J2735 message received by the RSU over the V2X Interface before forwarding to the Server.

children.name: rsuReceivedMsgRssi

discussion.comment: Delete reference to SAE J2735. Everywhere else we talk about this being any message and not all messages are defined in SAE J2735 (even in the US). The design should be broad enough to support and ETSI messages.

history.updatedComment: Delete reference to SAE J2735. Everywhere else we talk about this being any message and not all messages are defined in SAE J2735 (even in the US). The design should be broad enough to support and ETSI messages.

children.heading: Received Message Forwarding Interval
children.text:
<Definition> Interval with which RSU forwards messages received by the RSU over the V2X Interface to Server. For example, a value of 3 indicates every 3rd message received is forwarded (33% of the messages received). A value of 0 disables the message forward for this particular entry.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.7
children.name: rsuReceivedMsgInterval

discussion.comment:
Is this counter applied before or after filtering (e.g., based on signal strength, PSID)? I assume afterwards but it is ambiguous. e.g., revise to read:

Interval with which the RSU forwards messages meeting the corresponding filter criteria for the row. For exmple, a value of3 indicates that every third message received with a PSID of rsuReceivedMsgPsid and a signal strength of at least rsuReceivedMsgRssi is forwarded. A value of zero (0) disables this entry.

history.updatedComment: Is this counter applied before or after filtering (e.g., based on signal strength, PSID)? I assume afterwards but it is ambiguous.

children.heading: Received Message Forwarding Start Time
children.text:
<Definition> Start time for RSU to start forwarding SAE J2735 Messages to Server in UTC. DateAndTime is of length 8 octets. If a user attempts to SET this object to time that has already passed, the value of this object shall be equal to the date the current time (that this object was SET). For example, if a user attempts to SET this object to January 1 2023 12:00:00.0 (07 D6 01 01 0C 00 00 00), but the current time is February 1 2023 00:00:00.0 (07 D6 02 01 00 00 00 00), then this object will be SET to 07 D6 02 01 00 00 00 00.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.8
children.name: rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart

children.heading: Received Message Forwarding Stop Time
children.text:
<Definition> Stop time for RSU to stop forwarding SAE J2735 Messages to Server in UTC. DateAndTime is of length 8 octets. A badValue is returned if the management station attempts to SET this object to a stop time in the past.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.9
children.name: rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop

children.heading: Received Message Status
children.text:
<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for all objects contained in the corresponding row.

When this object has a value of 'active', an implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart, rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop, and this object for the corresponding row and should reject any request to modify any other object in the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while the current time is between rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart and rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop.

See Requirement 3.6.9 and 3.6.10 in the PRL for performance requirements.

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.10
children.name: rsuReceivedMsgStatus

discussion.comment: Revised text to conform to RFC 2579 recommendations.

attributesChanged.text:
<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Recommended practice: The values for a row in the rsuReceivedMsgPsid, rsuReceivedMsgDestIpAddr, rsuReceivedMsgDestPort, rsuReceivedMsgProtocol, rsuReceivedMsgRssi, rsuReceivedMsgInterval, rsuReceivedMsgSecure, rsuReceivedMsgAuthMsgInterval columns cannot be edited while rsuReceivedMsgStatus is 'active (1)', and the current time is between rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart and rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop.

See Requirement 3.6.9 in the PRL for performance requirements.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.10

<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for all objects contained in the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to modify the values of rsuReceivedMsgPsid, rsuReceivedMsgDestIpAddr, rsuReceivedMsgDestPort, rsuReceivedMsgProtocol, rsuReceivedMsgRssi, rsuReceivedMsgInterval, rsuReceivedMsgSecure, or rsuReceivedMsgAuthMsgInterval when rsuReceivedMsgStatus is 'active (1)' for the corresponding row. 

An implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart, rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop, and this object when this object is 'active' for the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while the current time is between rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart and rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop.

See Requirement 3.6.9 and 3.6.10 in the PRL for performance requirements.

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.10

children.heading: Received Message Forward Secure Option
children.text:
<Definition> A value of 0 indicates the RSU is to forward only the received message/PDU without the security header, signature and certificate. Messages are typically the SAE J2735 portion of the received WSM payload.

A value of 1 indicates the RSU is to forward the received SPDU (the entire received WSM payload), which includes the security header, message, signature and certificate. Refer to IEEE 1609.2 for the definition of SPDU.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.11
children.name: rsuReceivedMsgSecure

children.heading: Received Message Forward Secure Interval
children.text:
<Definition> Interval with which the RSU authenticates messages received from a specific device over the V2X Interface and to be forwarded to the Server (as controlled by rsuReceivedMsgInterval). If enabled, the RSU authenticates the first valid (e.g., as defined by rsuReceivedMsgRssi, rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart, rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop for this row) message received from a specific device. For a value of 4, the RSU then authenticates every 4th message (after the first message) for that specific device that is marked for forwarding (as determined by rsuReceivedMsgInterval). A value of 0 disables authentication of message to be forward for this particular entry.

For example, an RSU receives 12 messages that satisfies the criteria for this row (rsuReceivedMsgPsid, rsuReceivedMsgRssi, rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart, rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop). Messages 1, 2, 5, 6, 7, 10 and 12 are from device A and messages 3, 4, 8, 9 and 11 are from device B. Assuming rsuReceivedMsgInterval has a value of 2, only messages 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, and 11 are 'marked' for forwarding. Of these messages, only messages 1 (the first message from device A), 3 (the first message from device B), 7 (the 2nd message from device A after the first message), and 11 (the 2nd message from device B after the first message) are authenticated.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.5.2.1.12
children.name: rsuReceivedMsgAuthMsgInterval

children.heading: GNSS Allowable Location Deviation
children.text:
<Definition> Contains the maximum allowable deviation between the actual 2D GNSS coordinates of the RSU (rsuGnssLat, rsuGnssLon) and the reference GNSS coordinates (rsuLocationLat, rsuLocationLon). A value of 0 disables this feature.

children.heading: GNSS Location Deviation
children.text:
<Definition> The 2D deviation, in meters, between the reported GNSS coordinates (rsuGnssLat, rsuGnssLon) and the RSU's reference location (rsuLocationLat, rsuLocationLon).
<Valid Value Rule> Values of 0 to 19,999 provides a range from 0 to 19,999 meters. The value of 20,000 represents 20,000 meters or more. The value of 200001 represents unknown.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.6.10
children.name: rsuLocationDeviation

children.heading: RSU Position Error
children.text:
<Definition> Contains the estimated average position error in decimeters, at 67% confidence ((1) standard deviation). Values of 0 to 200,000 provides a range from 0 meters to 20,000 meters. The value of 200,001 represents unknown.
This value is provided by the GNSS receiver as part of each position report with 1-sigma confidence, which may be provided once per second.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.6.11

children.heading: Interface Log Name
children.text:
<Definition> Indicates the filename used when storing new interface data logs. This parameter shall be in the format <identifier>_<interface>_<direction>_<time> and contain only the following case-sensitive field names enclosed in chevrons (<>):
<identifier>: Identifier of the RSU. See rsuID.
<interface>: Identifier of the interface. See rsuIfaceName.
<direction>: Direction of communications. In for Inbound, Out for Outbound), and Both for inbound and outbound. Inbound is received over-the-air from the V2X radio.
<time>: In UTC. The time the file was opened. The format is YYYYMMDD_hhmmss, where YYYY is the four-digit year, MM is the two-digit month, DD is the two-digit day, hh is the two-digit hour, mm is the two-digit minute, and ss is the two-digit seconds.

Example: If the rsuID = rsu1, rsuIfaceName = dsrc1, both directions are collected in the same file, and the date and time the file was created is January 3, 2019, at 01:35:03, the filename would be rsu1_dsrc1_Both_20190103_013503.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7.2.1.8
children.name: rsuIfaceLogName

discussion.comment: See if we need to allow SnmpAdminString after other edits

history.updatedComment: See if we need to allow SnmpAdminString after other edits

children.heading: Interface Log Start Time
children.text:
<Definition> Interface Log start time in UTC. DateAndTime of length 8 octets. If a user attempts to SET this object to time that has already passed, the value of this object shall be equal to the date the current time (that this object was SET). For example, if a user attempts to SET this object to January 1 2023 12:00:00.0 (07 D6 01 01 0C 00 00 00), but the current time is February 1 2023 00:00:00.0 (07 D6 02 01 00 00 00 00), then this object will be SET to 07 D6 02 01 00 00 00 00.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7.2.1.9
children.name: rsuIfaceLogStart

children.heading: Interface Log Stop Time
children.text:
<Definition> Interface Log stop time in UTC. DateAndTime of length 8 octets. A badValue is returned if the management station attempts to SET this object to a stop time in the past.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7.2.1.10
children.name: rsuIfaceLogStop

children.heading: Interface Log Options
children.text:
<Definition> A bit-mapped value as defined below for configuring the message.
Bit 0 0=Delete oldest if disk full, 1=Stop if disk full
Bit 1 0=DoNotDelete, 1=Delete data log

Bit 0 - Indicates if the RSU is to delete the oldest interface data log file if the disk space for storing interface data logs is full, or to stop interface data logging. Default is to delete the oldest file
Bit 1 - Indicates if the RSU is to delete the corresponding interface data log file when an entry is destroyed in the rsuInterfaceLogTable. Default is not to delete the log file.
See Section 2.5 of RFC 3416 for encoding.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7.2.1.11
children.name: rsuIfaceLogOptions

children.heading: Interface Log Status
children.text:
<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for all objects contained in the corresponding row.

When this object has a value of 'active', an implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuIfaceGenerate and this object for the corresponding row and should reject any request to modify any other object in the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while rsuIfaceGenerate = 'on (1)'.

See Requirement 3.6.9 and 3.6.10 in the PRL for performance requirements.

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7.2.1.12
children.name: rsuIfaceLogStatus

discussion.comment: Revised text to conform to RFC 2579 recommendations.

attributesChanged.text:
<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Recommended practice: The values for a row in the rsuIfaceMaxFileSize, rsuIfaceMaxFileTime, rsuIfaceLogByDir, rsuIfaceName, rsuIfaceStoragePath, rsuIfaceLogName, rsuIfaceLogStart, rsuIfaceLogStop, and rsuIfaceLogOptions columns cannot be edited while rsuIfaceLogStatus is 'active (1)' and rsuIfaceGenerate = 'on (1)'.

See Requirement 3.6.9 in the PRL for performance requirements.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7.2.1.12

<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for all objects contained in the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to modify the values of rsuIfaceMaxFileSize, rsuIfaceMaxFileTime, rsuIfaceLogByDir, rsuIfaceName, rsuIfaceStoragePath, rsuIfaceLogName, rsuIfaceLogStart, rsuIfaceLogStop, or rsuIfaceLogOptions when rsuIfaceLogStatus is 'active (1)' for the corresponding row. 

An implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuIfaceGenerate and this object when this object is 'active' for the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while rsuIfaceGenerate = 'on (1)'.

See Requirement 3.6.9 and 3.6.10 in the PRL for performance requirements.

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7.2.1.12

<Definition> RowStatus as defined by RFC2579 with minimum support for active(1), notInService(2), notReady(3), createAndGo(4) and destroy(6).

Prior to creating a new row, a management station should be aware of all rows already in use.

This object shall have a status of 'notReady' unless valid values exist for all objects contained in the corresponding row.

When this object has a value of 'active', an implementation shall allow modifying the values of 

rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStart, rsuReceivedMsgDeliveryStop, and this object for the corresponding row and should reject any request to modify any other object in the corresponding row.An implementation should reject any request to modify the values of rsuIfaceMaxFileSize, rsuIfaceMaxFileTime, rsuIfaceLogByDir, rsuIfaceName, rsuIfaceStoragePath, rsuIfaceLogName, rsuIfaceLogStart, rsuIfaceLogStop, or rsuIfaceLogOptions when rsuIfaceLogStatus is 'active (1)' for the corresponding row. 

An implementation shall allow modifying the values of rsuIfaceGenerate and this object when this object is 'active' for the corresponding row.

An implementation should reject any request to change this object to 'notInService (2)' while rsuIfaceGenerate = 'on (1)'.

See Requirement 3.6.9 and 3.6.10 in the PRL for performance requirements.

children.heading: Security
children.text:
<Definition> A node containing information about cybersecurity credentials associated with the RSU.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7

attributesChanged.text:
<Definition> A node containing information about cybersecurity of the RSU (e.g., to central or a V2X link).
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.7

children.heading: Security Credentials Request
children.text:
<Definition> Provides configuration parameters for when an RSU should request new 1609.2 security credentials in hours, before existing credentials expire. A value of 0 indicates disabled, so the RSU never updates its certificates globally.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.1
children.name: rsuSecCredReq

children.heading: Enrollment Certificate Status
children.text:
<Definition> Provides the status of the enrollment certificates for the RSU.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.2
children.name: rsuSecEnrollCertStatus

children.heading: Enrollment Certificate Valid Region
children.text:
<Definition> Provides the valid country code, as defined by the United Nations M49 standard, that the enrollment certificates for the RSU is valid for, or 0 for 'other'. For the United States, the country code is 840.
Note: the M49 standard is the same as the ISO 3166 except some countries are omitted from the M49 standard.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.3
children.name: rsuSecEnrollCertValidRegion

children.heading: Enrollment Certificate Source Domain
children.text:
<Definition> Provides the domain resource locator (URL) of the Certificate Authority that is the source of the enrollment certificate.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.4
children.name: rsuSecEnrollCertUrl

children.heading: Enrollment Certificate Identifier
children.text:
<Definition> Provides the HashedId8 of the enrollment certificate identifier, derived as specified in 1609.2.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.5
children.name: rsuSecEnrollCertId

children.heading: Enrollment Certificate Expiration
children.text:
<Definition> Provides the date and time that the existing enrollment certificate expires. DateAndTime is of length 8 octets.
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.6
children.name: rsuSecEnrollCertExpiration

children.heading: Enrollment Certificate Source
children.text:

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.7
children.name: rsuSecuritySource

children.heading: Application Certificate Source

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.8
children.name: rsuSecAppCertUrl

<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.9
children.name: maxRsuSecAppCerts

children.heading: Application Certificate Table
children.text:
<Definition> Provides status information about application certificates for the RSU.
<TableType> static
<Object Identifier> 1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.4.2.18.8.10
children.name: rsuSecAppCertTable

history.removedComment:
